talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 3, page 3 (line 23), at the end of subsection (3), add "because of changes of a fundamental, durable and stable nature in the country concerned".
(2) Schedule 1, item 3, page 3 (after line 23), after subsection (3), insert:

(3A) If a notice under subsection (3) is published in the Gazette , the Minister must cause a copy of the notice to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 3 sitting days of that House after the publication of the notice, together with a statement that sets out the reasons for the notice, referring in particular to the Minister's reasons for thinking that changes of a fundamental, durable and stable nature have occurred in the country concerned.

para.inline: [section 37A—scrutiny of reasons for shortened visa period]

speech.para: (3) Schedule 1, item 3, page 3 (after line 30), at the end of section 37A, add:
(6) In this section:
country concerned means the country or countries in which the circumstances exist that give rise to the grant of temporary safe haven visas.

These are the amendments on sheet 1374. As I said yesterday in the second reading debate, the aim of these amendments is to introduce greater transparency into the minister's decision to extend or shorten the temporary safe haven visa. Conclusion 69 of the executive committee of the UNHCR outlines the condi tions under which repatriation of refugees could or should take place. It says:

Refugees may only be sent home where a change of circumstances in a country is of such a profound and enduring nature that refugees from that country no longer require international protection, provided that it is recognised that compelling reasons may for certain individuals support the continuation of refugee status.
It also says:

The executive committee stresses that in taking any decision on application of the cessation clauses based on circumstances, states must carefully assess the fundamental character of the changes in the country of nationality or origin, including the general human rights situation, as well as the particular cause of fear of persecution, in order to make sure in an objective and verifiable way that the situation which justified the granting of refugee status has ceased to exist.
It also says:
The executive committee underlines that an essential element in such assessment by states is the fundamental, stable and durable character of the changes.

Basically, it can be seen that the changes in Kosovo must be of a fundamental, stable and durable character. These are the criteria by which I would like to see the minister make his or her decision and to inform the parliament as to the reasons for such an assessment having been made. I am not saying that the minister will necessarily make a premature decision or one that does not meet the criteria, only that the possibility exists, especially given political volatilities in refugee issues.

Indeed, the possibility has occurred in the past. We saw that in 1996 several German state governments commenced the forcible repatriation of Bosnian refugees. Forcible in this case means premature. These refugees had been afforded only temporary protection by the federal government. Even before the German and Bosnian governments signed the repatriation agreement, expulsions began. The move was highly criticised by a wide range of humanitarian organisations, including the United Nations High Commission for Refugees and the United States Committee for Refugees, which called on the German government to postpone the repatriations. They pointed out:

Significant barriers to freedom of movement remain. The strong showing by nationalist candidates who have not renounced ethnic cleansing or partition, the uncertainty surrounding the postponed municipal elections and continuing reports of incidents of violence and intimidation all serve as further evidence that forced repatriation is premature.

It is even prophetic that in October of the same year, 1996, German and Yugoslav governments signed an agreement to repatriate back to Kosovo ethnic Albanians from Kosovo who were seeking asylum in Germany. They numbered more than 100,000. At the agreement signing in Bonn, the Yugoslav government representative said that deserters from the Yugoslav army would not face prosecutions upon return. All of Germany's high administrative courts that have issued rulings on Kosovo Albanians have rejected the notion that they are subject to persecution as a group.

My point is simple. Governments make mistakes. Ministers make mistakes. The cost of making a mistake in this situation is grave, and I would not like to see a similar thing happen in Australia if it came to deciding when Kosovo refugees should return. Requiring a statement by the minister does not mean that a mistake may never be made, especially in individual cases, and I will be moving to that a little later. But it does mean that there is a requirement that at least the minister has to look at the requirements of the UNHCR before making a final decision. I would like to indicate that I am appreciative of the government's willingness to support this amendment—

talk.start.para: —Which one is that?
—Amendments 1, 2 and 3 on page 1374. This is my first lot of amendments. I urge support from the Senate—
—Are you withdrawing the ones on sheet 1386?
—Perhaps I could deal with that when we get to it, Senator Schacht, but I am still moving it.

—I have just been asking, by way of kindly interjection, for an indication that the government will support the amendments from Senator Margetts on sheet No. 1374. The opposition has no objection to those amendments. Firstly, on behalf of the opposition I would like to express the view that, although we appreciate and are trying to cooperate with the government's business plans here in this chamber to get their legislation through and we agreed that this be non-controversial, it is clear that this legislation is of an important nature. The fact that there are amendments being moved by Senator Margetts indicates that from the beginning this legislation should have been dealt with in what you would call `controversial time'. There are many issues dealt with by this legislation which some of my colleagues, speaking in the second reading debate, indicated yesterday.

speech.para: Although we are supporting the government—and Senator Faulkner's remarks made it clear we are bipartisan with the government on this legislation—we do believe that, wherever possible, legislation of this nature should from the beginning be considered and debated in normal government business time so that all issues related to it can be considered. Even though the opposition is supporting this legislation, there are still plenty of questions to be asked and some of those were raised by my colleagues Senator Cooney and Senator McKiernan yesterday when they spoke.

The fact that Senator Margetts is raising questions and moving amendments today indicates to me that this is more than a non-controversial bill. Other senators who are yet to speak or make comments in the committee stage may express views about this and raise very important questions. I have already taken the opportunity, on behalf of the opposition, to give to the advisers to the minister some questions that we would like—if we can get them—some answers to by the end of this debate, which we have said we will try to finish within an hour. They are very relevant questions seeking information for the Australian public on the issue of refugees from Kosovo coming to Australia.

To save time yesterday I did not take my opportunity, as representing the shadow minister for ethnic affairs and immigration, Mr Sciacca, to speak in the second reading debate, but I want to make a few remarks here in the committee stage. Some two weeks ago I had the opportunity to visit refugee camps in Macedonia. I also had the opportunity to speak to four ministers of the Macedonian government and to speak to many Australian journalists and journalists of other nationalities who were and still are in Macedonia covering the awful human catastrophe of what is happening to the people being expelled from Kosovo and consequently becoming refugees.

One of the important things about this legislation that cannot be overlooked is that, although it is draconian in one sense because it means that nobody has the right to appeal for automatic refugee status—that being at the discretion of the minister—Mr Milosevic and his dictatorship cannot succeed in ethnically cleansing Kosovo. If it turns out that, because of the humanitarian nature of the Australian people, we are willing to accept 4,000 refugees from that region and that they are able to come here and may well apply to stay here permanently, that will be considered by Mr Milosevic as a victory. And that means that they will not return—or ever return—to Kosovo. That is exactly what he wants.

In my visit to Macedonia I had the opportunity to speak to the UNHCR representative there and he made it very clear that, although they very much welcomed the response of the Australian government, opposition and people to take 4,000 refugees, they were in no hurry for those refugees to come to Australia. This was for two reasons. One was that at that stage there had been no proper list compiled by UNHCR of all the refugees who had come out of Kosovo and were in at least 10 camps spread round Macedonia and Albania and they did not want to accidentally further separate family members by ending up having some people from one family sent to Australia, some to Canada, and some to Norway. So, until they had completed the list, had good records and made every effort to keep families together, they did not want people spread round the globe, particularly to places as far away as Australia.

The second thing that was made quite clear is that nobody supports ethnic cleansing or giving Mr Milosevic any comfort that he is succeeding in his dreadful program of getting rid of Albanians out of Kosovo. I think we should recognise why it is important to make it clear that these are temporary refugees coming to Australia but who will return to Kosovo. If we give any suggestion that they are going to become permanent residents of Australia, Mr Milosevic and his supporters in Belgrade will give it a great big tick and say, `We have succeeded.'

I have to say that while speaking to the refugees in the camps just outside Skopje I came across none who wanted other than to return to their homes in Kosovo. They want to go back and live there for the rest of their lives because that is where they and their forebears had lived for many generations. So we have to make sure that what we do in this parliament with this legislation gives an unmistakable signal that Australia does not in any way support ethnic cleansing, that we do not accidentally give that indication to Mr Milosevic.

I want to take this opportunity to also briefly say something about my talking to the refugees. It is often easy to be remote from the agony of these people and those elsewhere in the world, but from the several hours that I spent in two refugee camps talking at random to the refugees I can only say that an unmitigated horror, an atrocity, has been committed against hundreds of thousands of ordinary human beings.

These are people who were successfully living their lives in their homes—and, by the way, most of them are not poor peasants. They are not Third World peasants like you would have seen in a Cambodian, Sudanese or Burmese refugee camp; you are dealing with people who are well educated in the middle class/upper middle class who had comfortable lives and had very good houses in places such as Pristina. You are dealing with people who are tertiary educated—I met doctors, psychiatrists, school teachers, technicians and tradespeople—and even those from the farms are well educated and are running successful farms. You are not dealing with a Third World population of illiterate peasants.

At a minute's notice, they were told at gunpoint to get out of their homes and go. If they did not go, some of them were shot, some of them were beaten up and some of the women were raped. I have to say that it was extraordinarily difficult to listen to a young woman explain what was done to her by drunken Serbian militia and to know what to say to her as she described the indignity of what happened to her in one particular case.

I know it is hard to run diplomacy based on emotion, but I think it would be a good time for all politicians in the national parliament to listen to the horror and the endless stories, although uncorroborated as yet, of mayhem and murder, of people being shot as an example in front of their families, who were told, `This will happen to the rest of you if you do not get out, if you do not leave forthwith.' Most of them were given no more than between one and five minutes to leave their homes. As they left their homes and were marched down the street, they could see the Serb militia pillaging and burning their houses.

There were extraordinary stories of children under five years being taken from their families, who were told `If you don't pay us all the deutschmarks you have, you will never see your child again. You will have to buy them back in an auction.' This is what ethnic cleansing really means. It is not a purely theoretical thing that is devoid of what happens to people. It is dreadful. We must make sure that this parliament gives an unequivocal statement that we will never support ethnic cleansing, and that we will never support countries being based on only a racial, ethnic or religious nature.

President Clinton, two weeks ago in America, made a very important statement when he said that the Balkans cannot survive as a series of tin-pot countries, ethnically cleansed, with only one small pure ethnic group in each of those countries. As he said, we have to support multi-ethnic democracy in the Balkans because, if you do not, you would have to keep dividing the Balkans into smaller and smaller pure ethnic groups, and that would mean dividing every village and every town. That would not work, and in the long run we would leave a dreadful example.

Mr Milosevic makes it clear that he wants a greater Serbia. Ironically, he is creating a smaller and smaller Serbia by saying, `We want only a pure Serbia.' There is an opportunity in this bill for the parliament to say, `Yes, we are responding in a humanitarian way, but the refugees will go back to Kosovo,' even if it means for a generation that the United Nations—NATO and European countries in particular—have to have a peacekeeping force in those places to ensure that there is no more ethnic murder—no more ethnic cleansing.

There has been criticism of how countries like Macedonia and Albania have dealt with the refugees. In one week, nearly 200,000 people crossed the border into Albania. In proportion to the population, that is the equivalent of 1.8 million refugees arriving in Australia in one week. How do you think any Australian government would respond to that number of refugees arriving—being dumped—in our country within a week or two?

Other issues we have to deal with, which I do not have time to cover today, include the impact on countries like Macedonia, which is petrified—I have to put it as strongly as that—that it will be destroyed; that one way or the other it will be ethnically upset. They have a 25 per cent Albanian population, and there are ethnic Albanians in the government. They have been successful in Macedonia in establishing a multi-ethnic democracy—with many difficulties, I will admit. If they end up with two or three hundred thousand permanent Albanian refugees in Macedonia, the strain—both economically and socially—on the country will be immense, and they are worried it may draw them directly into the conflict. For example, one of the things I can see happening is the Kosovo Liberation Army operating out of the refugee camps in Macedonia. The Serb militia could come over the border and start fighting in Macedonia, chasing down the KLA, and thereby overturning the Macedonian government.

There are really important issues to consider. I understand the need for this bill to be passed quickly, to which the opposition has agreed, but to say that it is non-controversial and that we should have a restricted time for debate is incorrect, even though there is a very crowded agenda and other bills might appear to be more important. When we are dealing with the futures of several hundred thousand people who have been turned out of their homes in horrifying circumstances, it ought to be debated. We are willing to take refugees temporarily, and that issue ought to be given more time for debate.

I think many more senators would, in one form or other, like to take the opportunity to express their views. Therefore, although the opposition support this bill—and have supported it from the beginning because we understand the humanitarian nature of the issue we are dealing with—we also cannot give a signal to Mr Milosevic that his ethnic cleansing campaign is in any way going to succeed based on the humanitarianism of the Australian parliament and the Australian people to help these Albanian refugees. If we do take 4,000—or any number—let us make it clear that we want them to go back to their original homes, farms, towns and cities where they have lived successfully for many generations. That is the best way to defeat Mr Milosevic and his evil of ethnic cleansing.

talk.start.para: —I have something to add to what Senator Schacht has said. He was there recently, and the image he gave of people just being cleaned off the street, of coming home and having a minute to get out is a very evocative one. These are people, if they come here, that we can clearly identify with because it would be as if somebody had taken us off the streets of Canberra, Melbourne, Adelaide, Sydney, Perth, Darwin, Brisbane, Hobart or any other city and put us where we did not want to be.

speech.para: The bill will make it possible to bring those people here. It is a good bill and one that we all agree upon, to the extent that it allows that to happen, but it has what I see as a difficulty. We are saying in the bill that if any of these people for any reason want to stay or need to stay here there is a process to enable them to do that. It is a different process from the one that generally operates through the migration system because this system will be arbitrary in the sense that it depends upon the decision of a minister and it is not subject, as it should be, to what I call quality control.

I ask the parliamentary secretary: do the provisions for decision making in this bill, and the way that they can be reviewed, anticipate a debate we have not had yet but which to some extent is suggested by the Migration Legislation Amendment (Judicial Review) Bill? It seems to me that we do have a problem if we have these people, tortured as they have been, ripped from the place where they want to be, brought here and for whatever reason if they need to stay beyond three months, six months or ultimately to settle here, why is it that we do not have provisions that allow the decision making to be overseen by a process, either quasi-judicial or judicial?

talk.start.para: —I want to put on the record questions that I hope the minister can answer by the end of the committee stage. We have already given the questions to the adviser, but I want to quickly read these questions into the Hansard because I think they sum up many of the issues that are of concern to the general public. Firstly, can the minister give details of the selection criteria to be used by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and UNHCR in the selection of temporary safe haven candidates?
—I will be going through them one by one.
—You will read out the questions?
—Yes.

—There are 13 questions but, in that case, I will not read them out. I want to say that by the end of the debate we would like the questions to have been read out and the answers to have been given, otherwise it will be nonsensical for people reading the Hansard , and even for the record of this debate. So at this moment I will not go any further in reading them out.

—In speaking to Senator Margetts's amendment, which I understand is being supported by the government, I would like to formally indicate the Democrats' support for it. As I mentioned briefly during my second reading contribution on this legislation yesterday, it is of benefit to at least require the minister to have reference to some specific criteria in making his decision to enable people's visas to expire or to reduce the length of their safe haven visas. To that extent we do see it as an improvement. Nonetheless, we do still have concerns that the scope of the power the minister has to require people to be sent back to their country of origin is still extremely wide and not subject to appeal or any sort of review, and that it does not fully require consideration under the guidelines outlined by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

speech.para: Certainly that the country itself be safe to return to is important and obviously we would not want to send people back while bombs are still falling or there is still widespread conflict happening. One would assume that the government would not do that. But it is important to again acknowledge the individual circumstances of refugees and the fact that it is not simply a matter of the bombs having stopped falling or the killing having stopped. People may still have a well-founded fear of persecution, and indeed the conclusions of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees specifically emphasise that that type of cessation of refugee status still should not apply to refugees who continue to have a well-founded fear of persecution. That can be for any number of reasons. People may well have a fear for their safety despite the immediate intensive conflict having ceased, they may well not have a family to go back to, they may well not have a home or indeed a town to go back to. Those broader requirements and the broader conclusions of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees do need to be taken into account before any person is returned to their country of origin.

Of course, technically, as I said yesterday, under this legislation people coming here under a temporary safe haven visa will not be refugees in the legal sense of the word and that, in a sense, means the government does not have to apply the UNHCR guidelines. But I am sure all of us would acknowledge that in reality virtually all of them would quite easily fit the definition of a refugee and that it is only because of the government's insistence on this assistance being only temporary that the need to refer to the guidelines of the UNHCR is less pressing. Nonetheless, as I say, Senator Margetts's amendment is a positive one and we do support it.

I would mention briefly as well that—similar to Senator Schacht and in the interests of enabling this debate to proceed more quickly—as we have discussed with the government a couple of times, we will be putting in a number of written questions which I believe are important to have on the record as to the details of how these temporary safe haven visas will operate if, at some stage in the future, people are brought into the country under this legislation. Hopefully, we will get prompt responses from the minister on those.

talk.start.para: —I listened very carefully to what Senator Bartlett said. I want to emphasise that, if we suggest in any way that people will not be returned to Kosovo because they could claim that they have a well-founded fear of persecution—even though the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the European Community have said that a peacekeeping force will be present on there being a peace settlement; obviously things will still be not the way they were before the people were kicked out—that is only going to encourage Mr Milosevic to keep the pressure up and keep disturbances going in Kosovo to create the circumstances where people will claim they cannot go back or it is difficult for them to go back. That is the exact way this man is operating.

speech.para: We are not dealing with a rational human being who is interested in the United Nations charter of human rights. We are not dealing with a rational human being who believes that the judicial processes of Australia are there to help individual refugees. He wants to use our judicial process to make the point that they will not go back. You cannot say in this circumstance that the normal procedures work, because you are not dealing with a normal rational human being or administration. The refugees will tell you what they are dealing with. They are dealing with irrational madness that is killing them. That is Milosevic's policy.

I want to emphasise that, although Australians are rational people who will debate endlessly the role of how to handle refugees and the well-founded fear of persecution, that is the exact situation Milosevic will exploit so that people will not go back. So, if we have 4,000 Kosovo refugees here temporarily, they will all appeal and all apply to be here permanently, and that will be a big tick for Milosevic. We cannot give him that big tick, that victory. Although I have always had an interest in human rights and refugee issues, I know that, politically, if we allow our well-meaning concerns on human rights, civil processes and judicial review to operate, Milosevic will laugh and say, `Beauty, I have won. The Australians have fallen for the three-card trick. They will keep those refugees forever. I do not have 4,000 coming back.' If that happened all around the Western world, he will have ethnically changed Kosovo forever into being a Serbian area, or he will be able to divide it and keep at least half for himself. That is why I emphasise that the discretion in this legislation is necessary.

Can you imagine any minister—even a Liberal minister in a Liberal government—trying to force people back secretly? If any refugee was sent back against their will—because they were very scared that there was not a proper peace settlement or arrangement through the UN or the European Community to have a peacekeeping force there to maintain the peace—there would be such a debate in Australia and in this place the minister would end up being sacked. The major protection here is that if a minister used his discretion to force these refugees back into Kosovo, long before a peace settlement was reasonably reached and those rules had been established, there would be outrage in the Australian community. In this case, publicity and the issue itself is so important that no minister could use these rules of personal discretion to force refugees back. I cannot imagine a majority of senators sitting by—I certainly cannot imagine any opposition senator sitting by—and allowing a minister to use his discretion to force people back early. I cannot imagine that of any Democrat, Green or Independent senator who has an interest in this area. I suspect there are a large number of government senators also who would jump up and down. I think that is the major protection.

So, although this might appear to be a draconian piece of legislation in the sense that people's right of appeal is being removed from the normal refugee status, the minister has that broad discretion. He should have that discretion. And he should be held to account if he mucks it up, if he makes a mess of it. But let us make sure that, in the legislation itself, we are telling Mr Milosevic these refugees will return to their homes. They will hopefully return within six months as the legislation says, but if they need an extension for another six months then so be it. But we should never say outright that they are permanent residents of Australia, that they will be here permanently and the whole 4,000 can stay.

talk.start.para: —Who is saying that?

—I am not saying you are, Senator Margetts. All I am saying is that Mr Milosevic wants that position to occur. I do not want in any way to be part of indirectly supporting Milosevic and his evil policy of ethnic cleansing. That would be to say that he has succeeded, that he may have lost politically but ethnically he has succeeded as the refugees will never return.

—To say that the Migration Legislation Amendment (Temporary Safe Haven Visas) Bill 1999 , which we debated at lunchtime yesterday, is non-controversial is stretching the friendship a little. We all know that lunchtime on Wednesday is a time when we can discuss these bills. In an attempt to get this bill through, we sought the cooperation of honourable senators and we received it. There was an attempt to get it through at lunchtime, but obviously, because it is a bill of great importance, it is taking us a little longer. But the government was not really saying, in that sense, that it is a non-controversial bill; we were just seeking the cooperation of the Senate.

speech.para: I know that the minister's staff have offered all honourable senators briefings over and over again. I know people have taken advantage of that and I appreciate that. The minister's staff might have been able to answer some of these questions during those briefings, but Senator Bartlett has indicated he is willing to put questions on notice. I have made a commitment to Senator Bartlett that those questions will be answered before the bill goes back into the House of Representatives, which I presume will be in that week of the budget as early as possible. I have made a commitment that those answers will be back by 11 May. I appreciate Senator Bartlett's cooperation in giving me those questions and will do everything in my power to ensure that he has those answers. I have a commitment from the department and the minister that they will be answered by that date.

The question asked by Senator Barney Cooney was fairly well answered by Senator Schacht. Obviously, there will be a debate about that issue and we could probably stay here all day debating the rights and wrongs of that issue. Obviously, even on the opposite side there are slightly different points of view, but the most important thing for us to do is to assist the people whom we have committed to assist, if and when UNHCR indicates that they require us to take the 4,000 refugees we have committed to.
Senator Schacht gave me a list of questions and I will go through them as quickly as possible. I think these questions were asked in conjunction with Senator McKiernan.

talk.start.para: —Yes. They are Senator McKiernan's.

—Senator McKiernan is asking these questions. Question 1: can the minister give details of the selection criteria to be used by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and UNHCR in the selection of temporary safe haven candidates? That is set out in the Kosovo safeguard regulations item 448.2. They are in those regulations. Question 2: what amendments will need to be put in place to extend the six-month visas, if such an extension is needed in six months time? The answer is: a simple Gazette notice by the minister.

speech.para: Question 3: where in Australia will the temporary safe haven visa holders be domiciled? This is still under discussion, but initially they will be domiciled in East Hills army facility in Sydney and in Brighton in Tasmania, unless some of those people have relatives here with whom they wish to reside. Question 4: will temporary safe haven visa holders be housed or domiciled in military camps and installations? The answer is: at this stage, yes, but they will not be required to. As I said, if they have family or relatives here, they will of course be able to stay with them.

talk.start.para: —But they are the only two camps, East Hills and Brighton? We are not using Woomera and things like that?

—The advice I have is that the East Hills army facility and Brighton in Tasmania are the two at the moment. A final decision on other locations has not been made. Question 5: what is the estimated cost of providing accommodation in military facilities for the 4,000 proposed temporary safe haven visa recipients in Australia? I should take out the phrase `in military facilities', because obviously some will be with family. I will re-phrase that question: what is the estimated cost of providing accommodation for 4,000 proposed temporary safe haven visa recipients in Australia? The answer is: the estimated cost at the moment is $70 million for three months. Canada has estimated that the cost for 5,000 people for six months will be $Can100 million. They are operating in the same sort of ballpark.

speech.para: Question 6: what is the estimated cost of assisting community organisations to provide accommodation to the proposed 4,000 temporary safe haven visa recipients in Australia? We do not actually have an answer to that question. As honourable senators realise, these questions were actually given to us in the chamber and we do not have an answer. We will take that on notice and I will give the same commitment to the opposition that we gave to the Democrats, that we will get an answer back by 11 May before the bill goes into the House of Representatives.

Question 7: what is the estimated cost of providing medical and educational services to the proposed 4,000 temporary safe haven visa recipients? Question 8: what is the financial impact of this bill? Question 9: what are the estimated costs of transporting temporary safe haven visa holders to Australia? Question 10: have any moneys been allocated for torture and trauma counselling and other counselling services for temporary safe haven visa holders? Question 11: if, yes, how much? We do not have a breakdown of those questions here in the chamber at the moment. We will take those on notice and give them to you in the same time frame.

Question 12: will the minister give the Senate an assurance that funds already allocated to settlement services for refugee and humanitarian visa holders not be redirected to temporary safe haven visa holders? The answer that I have been given is, yes, the assurance will be given that funds already allocated will not be redirected. Questions 13: in the event of the visa being issued, when will the operative date commence? The answer to that question is: on the date of grant. They are the answers to those questions.

talk.start.para: —I appreciate the minister's quick response to the questions that Senator McKiernan prepared for the opposition. There are two things that come from these questions which we want to comment on. We appreciate that some of the answers could not be given. It is only reasonable that you take them on notice, and you have said the same to Senator Bartlett.

speech.para: There are two issues that we want to make clear. You have said that so far only two Army establishments are being considered, East Hills and Brighton in Tasmania. We do not have any objection to those as a temporary measure. We have made it clear that we thought using a place like Woomera was a bit odd. I have been to Macedonia and I understand the countryside there is very similar to the countryside in Kosovo. You would be taking people from that rather green and over-wet environment and putting them into Woomera within a 24-hour period. We have had plenty of desert experience in South Australia, but I do not think that anybody in Kosovo has had a desert experience in their lives. If they woke up the next morning and found themselves looking out over the Woomera gibber plain, they might suffer a bit of cultural shock.

Secondly, it is something like 600 kilometres from Adelaide and remote from any of the Albanian communities and other organisations who may wish to assist them. So we would certainly not support those sorts of military bases being used temporarily. Wherever possible, we encourage the government to put people with the Albanian community already in Australia. That would be, in humanitarian terms, a very sensible thing to do.

There is another issue I wish to comment on. The minister has estimated that, for three months, it would cost $70 million to bring the refugees here, keep them here and then send them back. And, if there are to be time extensions of six months, the cost would be multiples of $70 million or thereabouts. The opposition supported the government when it announced $6 million worth of humanitarian aid to Care Australia, UNHCR and International Red Cross.

I take this opportunity to congratulate and commend the Care Australia workers who I saw running one of the major camps outside Skopje. We can all be overwhelmingly proud of the work these Australians are doing. But I want to ask, Minister, that if we do not take 4,000 refugees—if we are not asked to take any—will the government consider using some or all of the $70 million they are willing to spend to have them in Australia as future money for economic rebuilding in Kosovo when the refugees go back?

This $70 million, or a proportion of it, is going to be needed to rebuild the homes that the Serb militia have destroyed. This is a large amount of money, and it is a significant amount of money compared to our AusAID budget. If we do not have to spend all of the $70 million in Australia—we have no objec tion to this and commend the government on having made this amount of money available—or if some of it or all of it is not spent, we would like some of this money spent as our commitment, in a humanitarian way, towards resettling the refugees in their original homes.

talk.start.para: —I do not remember whether I referred to Senator Margetts's amendments, but I want to say that the government will be supporting her amendments 1 to 3.

speech.para: With regard to where the refugees would be housed after they have been in the East Hills army facility in Brighton, that decision, as I have said to Senator Schacht, is still being finalised. Because each state would like to be involved, we have to take that into account. Those decisions are still being made and, as soon as they are finalised, I am sure the minister will advise the relevant people in the opposition and those people who have taken part in the debate today.

With regard to the commitment of the $70 million if the refugees are not brought to Australia, I think it is difficult to make any sort of commitment. It is within my minister's portfolio and then comes into another minister's portfolio, but I will draw the attention of both ministers to your comments.

talk.start.para: —I support the set of amendments currently before the chair made by Senator Margetts. The Migration Legislation Amendment (Temporary Safe Haven Visas) Bill 1999 is a heartfelt response by this government to the crisis in Kosovo and welcome news. However, I suppose it is understood around the chamber and, of course, by the government that the desire of those who have been forced out of their homes and homeland is to return. I believe that the aid and the diplomatic and other measures ought to be directed to that return. I think we all agree with that.

speech.para: This is, of course, going to be costly in terms of human cost—that is to say the transfer of some of the refugees to Australia will be at a human cost, perhaps dividing families, although I understand that department officials and the UNHCR are endeavouring to ensure that families are not split up. There is also a financial cost and one wonders whether that financial cost would not be better served in assisting the organisations, both non-government and government, on the ground there. A huge number of Australians have made personal contributions to those non-government organisations that are working in the area. There is some extremely good work being done—for example, the work of Caritas, and Care Australia has already been mentioned. I am also well aware of what is going on—the email is very handy—and I have a godson who has been in that area for a couple of years.
I will support the legislation. It is a heartfelt gesture and I am sure the government understands the desire of these people to return to their homes.

talk.start.para: —I need to respond to a couple of comments that Senator Schacht made. I will be as brief as I can. Again, I acknowledge the government's willingness to respond to the various questions that I have submitted to them, all of which are important but a few of which are of particular importance. The UNHCR executive committee's general conclusions on international protection are very important and need to be acknowledged in any debate on refugees. Going back to some of the comments of Senator Schacht, one is a strong emphasis on the need to ensure respect for the voluntary nature of any repatriation movement. That is a key question and a key issue that must be identified and emphasised.

speech.para: A number of people in the community have suggested that we should offer only temporary assistance because otherwise we would be playing into the hands of Milosevic and his ethnic cleansing. I certainly understand the concept behind that, but the reality of acting in that way is to dehumanise these refugees even further and to treat them simply as pawns in the political game between Milosevic and those who are trying to stop what he is doing. Of course they would want to return home. Everybody wants to return home. Unfortunately and very sadly these are not the only refugees in the world. I am sure all of those others would have liked to have returned home as well, initially, but the sad reality is that often that is not possible. Serbs at the moment are not exactly flavour of the month, but it needs to be emphasised that 100,000—

talk.start.para: —Milosevic, not Serbs. Separate the two. I never attacked the Serb people. It is Milosevic.
—I did not say you attacked the Serb people.
—You said Serb people are not flavour of the month. It is Milosevic that is not flavour of the month.

—I think it is a reasonably accurate statement to say that Serbian people as a whole, in media treatment at the moment, are not exactly flavour of the month. It needs to be emphasised that there are still hundreds of thousands of Serbian refugees from previous conflicts in the Balkans. I am sure all of those would have liked to have returned home. But to say that their not going home is somehow or another a vindication of the actions of those that pushed them out of their original place of residence is a silly statement. To say basically that we must refuse, on this particular occasion, the right of these refugees to have any choice themselves in their own future—for them to decide whether to go home—purely on the grounds that to do otherwise will make Milosevic happy is also a silly statement. We should be leaving the choice up to them. I am sure all of them would like to go home and hopefully that will be able to happen. But it is quite possible that it will not. That choice should be in their hands. They have already had their futures destroyed and lost control over their own lives. I think we need as much as possible to give them some control over their own future. That is one of my concerns with only offering temporary assistance. I seek leave to incorporate the questions that I was going to provide the minister.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Questions to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs
These questions relate to matters connected with the Migration Legislation Amendment (Temporary Safe Haven Visas) Bill 1999

The Minister's second reading speech stated that this Bill is "in addition to our commitment to work with the UNHCR to assist through permanent resettlement those people who may not be able to return to Kosovo". What specific measures is the Australian government taking to assist with permanent resettlement of these people?
Why has the Australian government refused to increase the size of our permanent refugee intake as part of this assistance to the UNHCR?

Is it the case that a holder of Temporary Safe Haven visa will not be able to appeal against any decision to shorten or cancel their visa in the High Court? Has the Minister received legal advice confirming that no appeal would be possible?

What criteria will be used in assessing people's suitability for a Temporary Safe Haven visa? Will potential recipients be specifically advised that receiving a Temporary Safe Haven visa will specifically preclude them from being able to apply for refugee status in Australia whilst they are in the country? Will people with existing connections with people in Australia be less likely than others to be granted a Temporary Safe Haven visa?
Can the Minister provide details on how the humanitarian aid being provided by the Australian government is being utilised?

Item (h) of the United Nations High Commission on Refugees Executive Committee's Conclusion number 65 points to "the responsibilities of states to resolve refugee situations and, especially with respect to countries of origin, to eliminate causes of refugee flows." What contribution is the Australian government making in this regard?

In response to a Question Without Notice the Minister indicated that "overseas posts process applications (for Humanitarian Program Visas) as a matter of priority" Where are such applications being processes? Are there any Australian government facilities in Albania or Macedonia to receive and/or process such applications?

The government has previously indicated that Temporary Safe Haven visa holders will only receive medical and other assistance at the specifically designated government residences. What will happen is a visa holder is out in the general community (e.g. visiting people or on a day trip) and gets sick or injured in an accident? Will they be required to be transported back to the designated residences to receive treatment?
Will any educational or other courses be provided to the Temporary Safe Haven visa holders whilst they are in Australia? If so, what?

What other countries outside Europe have also offered temporary asylum to people displaced from Kosovo? Which of these have also restricted the ability of such people to apply for permanent refugee status whilst they are receiving temporary asylum?
Will the Australian government be providing Temporary Safe Haven visa holders with identity cards or other documentation?

How many people from Kosovo displaced due to the current conflict are believed to be within Kosovo and how many are believed to be within Serbia? How many Serbian refugees are there still within Yugoslavia as a result of previous conflicts in the region? What measures are being taken by the international community to ensure their safety?

Is the government aware of reports that degraded uranium is being used in weapons in the current conflict? Are these reports accurate? What are the possible long-term environmental and health consequences of the use of such weapons? Has the government any information about the possible environmental and health consequences of other aspects of the current conflict?
Is it the case that involuntary repatriation of refugees is against international law? It is when they are refugees

How the does the approach being applied by the Australian government to the proposed 4000 Kosovo refugees differ from what was proposed under the refugee policy of the One Nation party released prior to the last federal election?
In what ways do the powers for cancelling a Temporary Safe Haven visa on character grounds differ from those which already exist in the Migration Act? What is the rationale for these differences?
Does the Temporary Safe Haven legislation bypass the Refugee Convention?
Isn't it true that it is the desire to maintain the 12,000 quota that has led to the 4,000 places being dealt with as Temporary Safe Haven?
Isn't it true that the cost of settling the Kosovo refugees temporarily, far exceeds the cost under the normal refugee program?

talk.start.para: —I thank the Senate. There are some important issues in there. They go back to my overall comments about the importance of the totality of the UNHCR's conclusions on international protection. Another of those items points to the responsibility of states to resolve refugee situations and especially, with respect to countries of origin, to eliminate causes of refugee flows.

speech.para: Whilst it may seem that this is a conflict on the other side of the world and there is not much we can do about it, the fact that Australia is not part of the conflict puts us in a position of being able to make moves to try and resolve the conflict to break the cycle of violence before it escalates even further—which I have great fears it is going to do. It is important to emphasise that that is a responsibility that we all have to try to work not just to deal with the consequences of what is happening but to actually stop it and stop the cycle of violence. I, for one, am certainly not convinced that, the way things are going at the moment, we are going in that direction at all.

Another important issue that needs to be considered in relation to the whole concept of whether or not people will be able to return home is what they will be returning to. That involves not just destruction of their villages and killing of their families but also indeed the very state of the environment that they are having to return to. Another question amongst those I have asked is: what details have emerged about the actual long-term environmental and health effects of the existing conflict? There have been a lot of reports in Western media about the use of depleted uranium in weapons. That has been alleged to be possibly responsible for Gulf War syndrome. Obviously in terms of the people there that are on the receiving end of these weapons, which includes ethnic Albanians as well as Serbs, what long-term health and environmental effects is that sort of activity going to have? Would we be again sending people back to an unsafe environment in the sense of a poisoned environment?

We have all seen the burning petrochemical plants, et cetera. Certainly there are reports of severe pollution of the rivers in the area. If we are expecting people to go back to somewhere safe, then we need to ensure that it is safe in the long term. Also, if action is being taken by any side in the conflict that increases that widespread environmental damage—an action which according to the Human Rights Watch is against the International Law governing the rules of war—then we as a country need make strong attempts to identify that, acknowledge that and prevent it from getting worse.

Acknowledging the reality of what is happening on all sides is a crucial component of being able to move forward. That was one of the key points that I heard made by a World Vision representative yesterday at a briefing dealing with the report that my colleague Senator Stott Despoja tabled in the Senate yesterday. It is important that we do not just look at dealing with the consequences of what is happening; we cannot disconnect that from the causes of this refugee flood. We need to do what we can to try and prevent it continuing and prevent the cycle of violence and similar atrocities happening in the future.
Amendments agreed to.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 7, page 5 (line 3), omit "it is in the public interest to do so,", substitute:
:(a) it is in the public interest to do so; or
(b) it is in the interests of a particular non-citizen to do so, having regard to any compelling reasons arising out of previous persecution of the non-citizen in the country concerned;
(2) Schedule 1, item 7, page 5 (after line 35), at the end of section 91L, add:
(7) In this section:
country concerned has the meaning given by section 37A.

These are the amendments to which I briefly alluded earlier. I apologise to the committee for the fact that these amendments were introduced later than the first ones. I believe that these amendments raise an important issue. I would like the committee to consider the issues, and at least have them on the record.

As it stands, provision has been made for the minister to allow a holder of a temporary safe haven visa to apply for permanent protection. I congratulate the minister for the fact that some provision has been made. However, the measure does not go far enough. The minister will only need to consider a person's request in terms of it being in the public interest. This excludes from the minister's deliberations persons who, for individual reasons of previous persecution, may wish to apply for permanent protection in Australia.

It is not good enough to make a decision that the visa is no longer valid and for all persons, except for some in the public interest, to then be sent home. Some individuals may have overwhelming, compelling reasons for not wanting to return home, even if, in the minister's assessment, stable conditions have returned.

I am not seeking that the minister be compelled in this decision, although some would say that that would be ideal. I am simply seeking that the bill conform to standards as laid down in the refugee convention, which states in article 1(c) that individuals have the right not to return to their country for a compelling reason.

I heard what Senator Schacht said. The disturbing element of what he said was that it indicated that the refugees, if they are in Australia, will still be part of the weapons of war. I can see that they are being used in many ways. In many ways, some people—and I mentioned this yesterday—would prefer that they be more visible in the Balkans. In many ways, my preference would be that Australia should provide the same, or more, resources to assist them to stay as close to their country as possible.

I agree with Senator Schacht that the vast majority of these refugees would probably prefer to go home; even with the offer of a temporary safe haven, they would probably want to go home. There is no suggestion whatsoever that 4,000 refugees would be accepted, or would want to, in any way, shape or form, stay here. The point that Senator Bartlett and I have been making as strongly as we can is that, for humanitarian reasons and under international conventions, to force a refugee to return home under those circumstances goes against everything we have ever signed up to.

Some are saying that these refugees should go home; that their sojourn here should only be temporary because that is what the Kosovars themselves want. They do not want to be refugees, whether it is in Albania, Macedonia or Australia. The overwhelming majority of refugees simply want to go home. I agree: let them go home. Let us even assist them to be able to go home. Let us continue to apply pressure to make sure that peaceful solutions are found wherever possible.

Let us also give them the choice as to when this happens—not whether this happens, but when. These people have already had their choices stripped from them at gunpoint, as Senator Schacht mentioned. If we are to provide no opportunity for individuals to apply for permanent protection based on their individual circumstances, we are effectively disempowering them—the final act in a long process of giving these people little choice in their own future.

I agree that, politically, there are people in the Balkans making absolutely outrageous decisions in terms of human rights. The use of radical nationalism by President Milosevic is, of course, despicable. I return to a comment I have made before in relation to some political forces within Australia: there is one thing worse than racism; that is, using racism for political benefits.

The same applies in relation to radical nationalism. There is one thing worse than being a radical nationalist; that is, to use radical nationalism to your political advantage. That, apparently, from what we see in the media, is what has happened in relation to President Milosevic. However, with regard to the situation in the Balkans, from what I can see—and I can only see it from this distance—there has been neighbour against neighbour in many instances. On both sides, there have been issues of neighbour against neighbour.

People in the Balkans do not know how they can communicate any more with the people they used to live with, not because President Milosevic is there but because nationalism, inappropriate hatred, fear and the incredibly complex conflicts that have built and fed for a long period of time have stirred people into such awful irrational behaviour that it might be impossible to go back, at least in the interim, to living where they were living. Their own personal circumstances may not be such that they can do that. I am simply saying that to use again each individual refugee as a weapon of war, to force them to go back, if some of them are—

talk.start.para: —Force them to go back?

—Well that is what it is. If you do not allow them the ability to plead their own case in a normal way, then yes you will have people forced to go back. That is the reality. Unfortunately, as I say, this means that once again we are using the same refugees as a weapon of war. If we are not prepared to do that, we should not be taking them. We should be giving that aid for them to stay as close as possible to their country, to be as visible as possible to the rest of the world, and to assist them to live until they can do that. If we are taking them, we do not basically use them again as a weapon of war. It is unconscionable to be doing that.

speech.para: I know the opposition is not prepared to support this. I know the government is not prepared to support this, but it must be put on record now that we cannot allow this to go by without comment and suggest that this is a good way to make legislation. We know that there is generosity in the way the government is acting, but there are issues about the way you treat refugees. I do not think anyone here is saying that we are not dealing with genuine refugees, but there is a point at which we should not disempower human beings any further than they have been disempowered.

talk.start.para: —The opposition does not support these amendments. We do not believe they are necessary. Concerning the argument put by Senator Margetts in the wider context of her concern about process and about handling refugees, I have already expressed my view that the basic issue here is: will Mr Milosevic—not the Serbian people; I make a very strong distinction between the Serbian people and Mr Milosevic and his regime—get away with imposing and succeeding by, de facto, his policies of ethnic cleansing?

speech.para: I agree that there can be criticism of the Western world, that the refugees who were displaced from Bosnia and Croatia who have a Serbian background—I understand about 600,000 who were displaced are now back in Serbia—also should have been dealt with in a wider context, but that is the outcome which Mr Milosevic was willing to embark upon in the early 1990s with ethnic cleansing. The tragedy is that his own Serbian people, ethnic Serbians from Croatia, Bosnia and Slovenia, have also suffered. That is why it is a crazy policy. If you try to divide the Balkans based on ethnicity, you are going to end up hurting your own people as well. That is why our commitment to multi-ethnic democracies in the Balkans is the only way to proceed.

The remark that we will be further disempowering refugees who may come to Australia is a very narrow point; the real disempowering has come from the fact that these refugees, in horrible circumstances, have been forced to leave their homes where they were more than happy to live for the rest of their lives.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of Senator Bartlett and the Democrats, I would like to indicate the support of the Democrats for the amendments moved by Senator Margetts. I hope the government will appreciate the discipline with which the Democrats have approached this debate.

speech.para: I would like the opportunity to comment briefly on the amendments, on the Migration Legislation Amendment (Temporary Safe Haven Visas) Bill 1999 and on some of the things that have been said. I begin where Senator Schacht left off. Certainly, he is in a position to know some of the incredible circumstances in which the refugees from Kosovo are living. He also would know first-hand from visiting the various camps some of the atrocities to which they have been subjected and some of the horrific things that people have endured.

I know that all senators have an interest in this debate. I am not surprised that it has been a rather controversial and reasonably passionate debate. My personal interest in this debate has been deepened as a result of visiting Albanian Kosovar refugees in Albania, in and around Tirana, and seeing refugees in the whole gamut of circumstances—camps, hostels, hotels that have been turned into refugee camps, and people living in cars, trucks and other people's homes.

The point that Senator Harradine makes about the division of families is important. Families are already being divided, people have already lost husbands and children and literally have missing persons being hunted every day of the week, trying desperately to find their loved ones. I think we should bear that in mind in relation to families and how they will be treated or accommodated when they come to Australia, if indeed refugees do come to Australia, depending on what the UN determines.

Concerning housing, I pick up Senator Schacht's point about Woomera. Obviously as South Australians, we both live in the driest state in the driest continent and culture shock is probably an understatement in relation to how refugees coming from the mountainous and very different climate in the Balkans would respond to South Australian conditions.

To put on record, as Senator Bartlett has done, the Democrats' position on the bill, we have always believed the best way to help these refugees is through the provision of additional funding and technical assistance, both for where the refugees are now and with permanent refugee places under the program as it currently exists. We believe that should have been done through an increase in the size of the program. We maintain that offering temporary haven to these people has a number of disadvantages. We think there is the possibility that we will compound the trauma that many of these people have experienced.

I understand Senator Schacht's logic very well, but I think when you ask refugees in the camps whether they want to go home, of course they will say that they want to go home to a safe and free environment. I do not think anyone in this chamber would suggest that anything else was appropriate, but how we achieve that is another issue. When Senator Margetts talks about empowering refugees, or the possibility of disempowering refugees, she refers to the freedom of choice that we are essentially asking be given to these people. Providing a safe haven is one thing, but providing the freedom of choice for refugees to make the decision whether or not to stay in our country or go back to their community is another. I too am very wary of playing into the hands of Milosevic.

I see that Senator Patterson is getting anxious so I will not prolong the debate. I thought it was important to raise this matter, given that the one question I had yesterday from Senator Patterson about my trip was `Who paid for it?' Some of these issues are life and death matters, and I do not think asking for a few minutes of the Senate's time, given the role of the Australian government and community in such a crisis, is too much to ask. I commend the government for the fact that, in some respects, it has extended a helping hand. Like Senator Harradine, Senator Schacht and others, I commend the humanitarian and aid groups who are working tirelessly. I also commend the members of the community who have given donations. This bill has shortcomings; it is inadequate. We will be supporting the amendments put forward by the Greens. Without meaning to be too sarcastic, I thank the government for the opportunity for people to speak on the bill. I do not understand why the debate has been rushed on such an important matter.

talk.start.para: —I will not respond to the comment about rushing the bill. I appreciate, without being cynical either, the cooperation of honourable senators to try to facilitate this bill. I think we all realise the urgency of it. With regard to the amendments moved by Senator Margetts, we will not be supporting them because the formulation used in section 91L of the bill, which allows the minister to permit an application for another visa to be made, is the same as that used for other similar noncompellable powers. For example, section 91F allows the minister to permit a visa application to be made by a person who has come from a safe third country. This provision is about the making of an application for a visa. The amendment would require the minister to make a detailed assessment of matters which would be assessed when the application was considered. Contrary to the view put forward by Senator Margetts, public interest is a very broad term and it is wide enough to allow the minister to consider the circumstances of any person.

—I remind honourable senators that it will not be in normal circumstances. We know the difficulties with legal advice and we also know that, under this bill, there will be no appeal. So it is not a normal situation; it would be very limited. We are also dealing with the potential of some people going home, and some people having to go with the person who is being rejected and other things. We still think the ability for people to argue on an individual case is important.

speech.para: Amendments not agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I have one other question that I want to put on notice. I have not put it with the ones in writing because it is more of a policy question and it is a bit hard to incorporate it as a written question. As everyone knows, prior to the government's change of position on this issue, Minister Ruddock had ruled out a temporary option when he questioned the appropriateness of that. He outlined some of the reasons why that was not a good way to go. I do not raise that to make a cheap shot; I just raise it as a matter of fact.

speech.para: As we are now going down this track, I am interested in getting some indication from the government about whether they see this as a one-off or whether it may serve to be a precedent for similar treatment in comparable circumstances. I am sure we all hope that this will never happen again but, the world being what it is, sadly it probably will. I am interested to hear from the government about the precedent issues in relation to this bill.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

talk.start.para: —We are discussing 27 bills, although it is fewer than that in committee. I am not sure whether Senator Campbell will be handling the cognate debate on these bills. He might indicate that to me and we might move it along. Senator Campbell, are you handling this for the minister at the moment?
—Here he is.

—I welcome the minister. I was not actually due to make my contribution on the bills for another five weeks, so I will have to go back to my office and prepare that contribution now. I will let you get on with the proceedings.
—The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Margetts to Senator Murray's amendment be agreed to.

—In wrapping up the debate on this issue, I must make some short remarks. The first thing I need to do is to respond to Senator Cook's question the day before last as to why the Democrats had abstained on a particular amendment which he thought was unusual given the content of the amendment. The reason we did so is that we think that amendment did not go far enough, and we have introduced amendments to correct the very issues that Senator Cook has outlined.

speech.para: I am fully aware of the Labor Party's position on the GST, but the areas to which he referred in fact concerned income tax cuts. As both the Labor Party and we appreciate, nearly all those income tax cuts could go through without the GST bills at all. They can be funded separately. It is our intention to improve on inadequate and somewhat symbolic Labor Party second reading amendments by putting very material amendments to the income tax cuts bills which will deliver the outcomes which Senator Cook and his party profess to support, and I have no reason to doubt that that profession is not genuine.

Therefore, Senator Cook, our abstention the other day was designed to test your commitment to those issues. You have now established your threshold. When we come to the amendments which we have put to correct those ills that you have outlined, we will test your commitment at that time. Those will not be GST bills and we will be looking to make sure that you vote with us on that issue. So, if you like, there was a bit of a tactical test under way for your principles and for the way in which you approach that.

The final short remarks I wish to make on this particular amendment that the Australian Democrats put is that, for us, it was a threshold question. We wished to make clear, and it was for the parliament to make clear, that tax changes of this scale should not be countenanced by either the country, the parliament or the Senate unless they contain a genuinely progressive redistributive mechanism. We are firmly of the opinion—and I gather from all the non-government speakers that they are firmly of that opinion too—that the overall package in terms of the redistributive principle is regressive and that it in fact makes the rich and the better off much better off and does very little to advance the cause of the poor and the disadvantaged—the lower class and middle class in old class terminology.

We are convinced that the package makes millions of Australians worse off, and they are all at the lower end of the spectrum. So, if the package is designed to make millions of Australians at the lower end worse off and millions of Australians at the upper end better off, you can see why the non-government parties would adopt a position of either total opposition or requiring radical amendments. That is why we set out to try to establish a threshold position and philosophy against which this debate should proceed. Given the range and scale of debate on the issue of fairness which we have enjoyed over the last two days, I do not think I need say much more in wrapping up. I, therefore, urge that we move to the vote.

talk.start.para: —I can indicate on behalf of the Labor Party, the opposition, that I accept your urgings, Senator Murray, and I am happy to move to the vote. I have spoken in this debate on a couple of occasions and my remarks have been directed principally at subclause (b) of the amendment you are proposing, 1-4, the intention of parliament amendment. I will not go over that ground again, having put it on the record previously, save to say that the notion that you express in that provision—that the weight of the taxation system should be borne heaviest by those who can afford it and be borne lightest by those who cannot afford it—is of course a notion fundamental to the philosophy of the Labor Party. However, we think, with the greatest respect to you, that putting that philosophy in a bill for a GST, which is a regressive tax and which redistributes the load heaviest on those who can least afford it, saying that that was our intention but the legislation unfortunately got in the way and our intention was not delivered, makes a bit of a nonsense of that.

speech.para: I have not spoken on subclause (a), though, and I will do so very briefly, in the expectation that that will conclude the Labor Party's participation in the debate on this point. You say in there that this tax system should be fairer than the wholesale sales tax system it replaces. The wholesale sales tax system is not a perfect system, and the government has tried to cast the Labor Party in the role of defending to the last letter the existing tax system. At the last election we went to the people with a view of tax reform of our own, and our view of tax reform was a policy which significantly changed the current system but left intact the wholesale sales tax system, with modifications. So the first point I make is that, while we will hear the government explaining to the people what the Labor position is, I would much prefer, as a Labor spokesperson, for us to explain it to the people ourselves, to describe our policy initiatives appropriately and properly and not have them misdescribed for the purposes of winning a political point by the government. But I do not want to spend a lot of time on this.

talk.start.para: —Spend some time.

—If you want me to canvass our tax policy position at this stage and if that is the intent of the interjection, I will. I do not think it is in the interests of the chamber at the moment for us to necessarily move to that, but I am delighted to accommodate such a debate should it be desired by the government.
—Senator Cook, I will not allow you to accommodate that debate. I ask you to direct your remarks through the chair and I ask that interjections on my right cease.

—The fundamental point of our proposals to change the tax system is that they do not have a GST. You can have tax reform in this country without a GST. The idea that tax reform necessarily involves a GST is a fraudulent idea. The idea that what the government has put forward is tax reform is a matter of opinion. That might be its opinion, but it is not a matter of fact. You cannot say that this is tax reform. Tax reform is a matter of judgment, and in our judgment, and in the judgment of 52 per cent of the electorate at the last elections, a GST is not tax reform.

speech.para: The second major feature of our tax reform policy was to overcome the poverty traps that are recurrent in the present system. The inquiry we had received particular evidence towards the very end of it, unfortunately in a manner in which we were unable to explore it to the extent which many of us—including, to be fair, government members of the committee too—would have liked to do. It was evidence about tax credits. The nub of our policy at the last election was to overcome poverty traps by introducing a system of tax credits. That has been referred to in this debate by the Democrats as well. Without trying to misrepresent them but speaking frankly about how I understand what they said, I think they spoke of tax credits in approving terms and in terms that this is a concept well worth exploring further.

If you remove poverty traps from the system, you do encourage people to find work and you do encourage people away from welfare in the most positive way. I have to acknowledge that there would be fewer poverty traps if this bill were to go through than there are currently, but there are still a significant number and they are still a significant deterrent for a large percentage of Australians. If you have a system which removes poverty traps, you do not have a system in which people are reliant on welfare. They do seek work, and that is a positive element of the tax system that we are concerned to promote. But that does not mean to say that the wholesale sales tax system of itself is to be taken by the scruff of the neck and thrown out. It should not be.

The government in public debate have derided the wholesale sales tax system on the basis that there are different levels of taxation. They say their system is better because there is one level, 10 per cent across the board, whereas the wholesale sales tax system has different levels of taxation. The government are wrong. The reason that I cannot support this part of the amendment is that it is simplistic to say that all consumption is equal. Consumption involves luxury goods, high quality superior goods, middle goods, lower quality goods and essentials of life. If you tax all of those as if they are equal, you deny the distinctions between the classes of goods. We think it is appropriate that where there are taxes on goods—the wholesale sales tax system taxes goods, not services—you ought to have regard to the type of good and the importance to a family that good has and you ought to distinguish the gradations of luxury, exclusivity or elitism in the types of goods families purchase. This means placing the burden of taxation on luxury and elite goods rather than placing the burden of taxation equally on all goods.

I am afraid I may not have explained that concept as clearly I would have liked, but that, I am sure, is a concept that ought to be recognised by the chamber because we have been in this debate for some time. However, the Democrats' amendment suggests that the system that we are to replace the wholesale sales tax system with is a fairer system than the wholesale sales tax system. That is a fundamental contention. It is a contention to which we do not subscribe, because we do think it is essential to distinguish between types of goods and their importance to families and existence—the optional types of goods that go to the comforts of life or the optional goods that people consume that go to high luxury items—and to tax the more exclusive goods at a higher rate than the other goods. So I cannot support part (a) of the amendment moved by the Democrats. My concluding remark—let me assure the chamber—on this amendment is that there is a further amendment moved by the Greens.

talk.start.para: —That has been disposed of.
—That amendment has been incorporated into this amendment, as I understand it, and not withdrawn.
—No, it was defeated first thing this morning.
—We had a vote on it.
—You had a vote on it. Well, I missed the vote; shame on me. But that removes from me at least the need to actually address that matter if it is no longer before us.
—It has been dealt with, Senator.
—It has been dealt with; thank you. For those reasons the Labor Party will not be supporting this amendment.

—The amendment before us is an amendment to state the intention of the parliament in respect of the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Bill 1998 . It has been made very clear by the mover of the amendment, Senator Murray, as the amendment says, that:

speech.para: It is the intention of the Parliament that this Act and associated laws for A New Tax System:
(a) be fairer than the Wholesales Sales Tax system they replace; and
(b) promote redistribution of the load of the tax system from the poor to the rich.

Should at the end of the day the parliament as a whole pass legislation entitled the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Bill which achieves those objectives, I say to Senator Murray and the chamber that would be a triumph of hope over expectation. If that occurs as a result of what has been done here and as a result of a government considering the concerns that have been expressed, that would be well justified. There is a need, as the government ought to know from the debate, for major structural changes to this legislation to achieve these objectives.

I know that true hope is an expectant hope. Expectancy is an essential element of true hope.
