But it is hope in what and hope in whom and, as yet, I do not think the chamber has been given any indication whatsoever by the government that that expectant hope would be justified. We could save a lot of the time of this chamber if the government were to indicate the major structural changes that they would see necessary to achieve the particular intention that has been proposed by Senator Murray.

talk.start.para: —I will make a very brief concluding comment. First of all, I thought an issue which was raised briefly by Senator Cooney was interesting. I think Senator Cooney's remarks, if I can summarise them briefly, were that he could see some problems if the amendment were accepted because of the inevitable role that the courts would play in making interpretations on matters which are more properly the preserve of the parliament. In relation to Senator Cooney's comments, I draw the Senate's attention to division 182. It is made clear in that division that statements in chapter 1 can be used in interpreting an operative position. No-one argues that this package should not be fair. The government feels it is fair. Others have other opinions and the government will obviously listen very closely to the debate as it proceeds and as particular issues emerge. But I think Senator Cooney did raise an interesting point. I am not aware whether in these types of tax bills it is normal to have this type of clause. My advisers tell me this would be exceedingly unusual and it would, as I think Senator Cooney indicated, involve the courts in matters which are more properly the preserve of the parliament.

speech.para: I have stated at some length the government's objectives on this bill. I read from the ANTS package where the government outlined in considerable detail the objectives that we set forth. Fairness of course is an extremely important aspect of them. Another aspect is the need to encourage small business, to encourage growth and to encourage employment. There is the need to reform federal-state financial relations, and it is clear from the recent Premiers Conference that substantial progress has been made on that score. I think I have responded to Senator Cooney's comments. I can assure Senator Harradine that the government will listen to the debate as it proceeds. We believe the package is a fair package.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Murray's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —Before we move on to the next amendments, I would like to make a statement in relation to these bills. Certain of the government amendments to these bills have been drafted in the form of requests. The government drafters have explained that this is because, although neither bill imposes tax or appropriates money, some of the amendments may widen the impact of the tax and that may result in persons paying more tax while others, potentially, may increase expenditure under a standing appropriation in other legislation. These have not been regarded as sufficient grounds for putting amendments in the form of requests on the past precedence of the Senate. In any event, the explanatory memorandum accompanying the amendments states that their financial impact is negligible, indicating that it is not thought that in practice they will have the effects postulated to any significant extent. The amendments will therefore be treated as amendments.
—by leave—I move:

speech.para: (1) Clause 27-30, page 53 (line 27), at the end of the heading, add "to take account of changes in tax periods ".
(2) Page 54 (after line 23), after clause 27-35, insert:

para.inline: 27-37 Special determination of tax periods on request

speech.para: (1) The Commissioner may, in accordance with a request you make in the *approved form, determine the tax periods applying to you to be the tax periods specified in the request if the Commissioner is satisfied that:
(a) your *annual turnover meets the *tax period turnover threshold; and
(b) the tax periods specified in the request are consistent with the commercial accounting periods that apply to you; and
(c) the tax periods specified in the request would, if determined under this section, result in 12 complete tax periods in each year; and
(d) any other requirements specified in the regulations are complied with.
Note: Refusing a request for a determination under this section is a reviewable GST decision (see Division 7 of Part VI of the Taxation Administration Act 1953 ).
(2) A determination under this section overrides any determination under section 27-15 or 27-30 relating to tax periods applying to you.
(3) Page 54 (after line 23), after clause 27-37, insert:

para.inline: 27-38 Revoking special determination of tax periods

speech.para: (1) The Commissioner must revoke a determination under section 27-37 if the Commissioner is satisfied that any of the requirements of paragraphs 27-37(1)(a), (b), (c) and (d) are not complied with.
Note: Revoking a determination under this section is a reviewable GST decision (see Division 7 of Part VI of the Taxation Administration Act 1953 ).
(2) The revocation takes effect on the day specified in the instrument of revocation. However, the day specified must be 1 January, 1 April, 1 July or 1 October.
Note: Deciding the date of effect of the revocation is a reviewable GST decision (see Division 7 of Part VI of the Taxation Administration Act 1953 ).
(3) A revocation under this section revives any election under section 27-10, or any determination under section 27-15 or 27-30, relating to tax periods applying to you.

Under the current bill GST tax periods generally end on the last day of a month. But there is a provision to allow a GST-registered person to vary this by seven days before or after the end of the month. While this suits most taxpayers, some very large taxpayers use different accounting periods for particular reasons and the final day of their usual accounting period does not always fall within the required seven days before or after the end of the month. For example, some existing arrangements use four five-week periods and eight four-week periods annually while others use 13 four-week periods. It has been the government's stated intention that its reform should wherever possible utilise existing business arrangements. These amendments now before the chamber will provide more flexibility so that the commissioner can allow different tax periods in special circumstances.

talk.start.para: —As the minister indicated, these amendments do allow for tax periods other than monthly tax periods to accord with entities' commercial accounting practices. The Greens (WA) believe this is good for flexibility and that it does reduce compliance costs without much impact on the Australian Taxation Office. It does, I guess, increase the power of the tax commissioner but, in general, the Greens (WA) support these amendments.

—We have moved to government amendments Nos 1 to 3 on sheet FA209 which are being moved together by the government. Part 2.6, which is being amended by these amendments, deals with tax periods and the general rule is that a tax period is three months, ending on 31 March, 30 June, 30 September or 31 December. I note that those are months, not weekly periods or an accumulation of weekly periods.

speech.para: A person can elect to have a tax period of one month. If the business has turnover in excess of $20 million it has a tax period of one month. Amendment 1 from the government is an amendment to the heading of clause 27-30 to more accurately reflect the content of that clause, and that seems straightforward. Amendment 3 inserts a new clause which obliges the commissioner to revoke a determination if any of the requirements of that clause are not complied with, and that seems straightforward.

But I have a question concerning amendment 2, Minister. Amendment 2 inserts new clause 27-37 which permits the Commissioner of Taxation to determine special tax periods for businesses with a turnover of more than $20 million. The specification of the period must still result in 12 complete tax periods for the year. The explanatory memorandum provides the example of some entities having 12 accounting periods which do not necessarily coincide with calendar months—in other words, some will be four weeks and others five weeks; that is why I drew your attention to the difference between periods which are set with months as opposed to those which are set with weeks.

Minister, page 8 of the explanatory memorandum, at point 1.5, gives the example that some entities have 13 four-week accounting periods, and clause 27-37 provides that the determination must result in 12 complete tax periods. Does that mean at least 12 complete tax periods? If not, how will businesses that have 13 four-weekly accounting periods, as specified in your example, be assisted by this amendment? In other words, is there any difficulty for companies which have 13 four-weekly accounting periods as compared with the legislation, which specifies 12 complete tax periods?

talk.start.para: —The advice I have is that in practice some returns are aggregated, so in fact 12 returns are lodged.

—As you know with these answers, your response matters in terms of the interpretation that will be put on these things by the Commissioner of Taxation. I doubt if this is a matter that will go to the courts. If I understand your response correctly, you are saying that the flexibility exists in the law for the tax commissioner to accept 13 four-weekly tax accounting periods as operated by a company?

—My advice is that a similar process currently exists under the sales tax arrangements and these amendments provide a legal basis for the commissioner to have a similar ruling in relation to the goods and services tax.
—So, to clarify, Minister, you are saying that it is a continuation of existing tax practice and businesses should expect no change from that?
—Senator, I have always been told that you should not ever answer a question with yes, because things may be slightly qualified, but there was vigorous nodding from my advisers, so the answer is yes.
—With that clarification, the Australian Democrats indicate that they will support government amendments 1 to 3.

—These are the first government amendments that have come before the chamber of the 27 GST bills we have to consider. I want to say a couple of things from the Labor Party point of view about how we will approach the government amendments to a package of bills that we oppose. I do not need to state for the record—because I have said it often enough, and certainly the Leader of the Australian Labor Party, Kim Beazley, has made it publicly clear—that we are opposed to a GST. That is our sentence—we are opposed to a GST—and it does not brook any further interpretation. We are opposed to a GST and there are no ifs, buts or maybes in that. But we have government legislation here and our view may not prevail.

speech.para: The government is proposing on this occasion 128 amendments to its own legislation. That is 128 amendments to the legislation it put through with a guillotine in the House of Representatives before Christmas. It has now found flaws in that legislation which it rushed through the House. It wants this chamber to be compliant in amending many of those flaws. It classes the amendments it has put as technical, machinery or minor amendments. We do not think that all of the amendments are minor. One of those was referred to yesterday—that is, the casino amendment. We do not think that is minor. I made my position clear on that yesterday. We are opposed to it and, when the amendment comes along, we will not support it.

But some of these machinery amendments are amendments that you would class in the category of sensible and good law. I hope we do not lose our argument, but if we do it is obvious that the actual change should work. We think that the government has not disclosed all of the amendments that it will propose to this chamber. Even though this debate has been going for almost a fortnight, just looking at the drafting of this bill—leaving aside the wider issues of structure or any concessions it might wish to make in offstage negotiations outside of the Senate with parties or people in this chamber—and looking at the technical expression of this bill and of some of the other bills, we believe that there are some technical flaws which the government will have to come back and amend further. Either it will do so during this debate, which now appears likely to extend into the budget sittings, or if it got its way against our opposition and this legislation was carried in this chamber and became law, having established the principle of a GST—something to which we are opposed—then at its leisure, later this year or next year, it will come back and beseech this chamber to correct some of the drafting errors and mistakes that it has made.

So we do not think that if this legislation were carried—something that we hope does not occur—that would be the end of it. We think there are a number of devils in the detail—technical problems and difficulties—which, if this legislation were implemented, would create considerable obligations and problems, higher costs and administrative charges for business in Australia and problems in the implementation which will inevitably require further and further amendment. We will not oppose these amendments, because we think they are machinery amendments.

I say for the record that we in fact proposed amendments to the government's legislation disposed of earlier—the GST fringe benefits tax legislation—because it dealt with anti-avoidance issues. That is, we constructively played a role to make the anti-avoidance provisions, under the GST FBT legislation, more effective and the government accepted our amendments on that occasion. We did so because we believe all taxpayers should pay the appropriate amount of tax and the anti-avoidance provisions should express clearly how they make sure that no-one escapes their proper obligation. So we played a constructive role on anti-avoidance and, where it is appropriate, we will continue to play that constructive role in making sure that the legislation is workable. But, with those remarks as a general approach, I say that none of our activities in not opposing technical amendments by the government should be construed or used in debate as the Labor Party supporting a GST. Emphatically, we do not. But it would be silly not to allow a provision that the government might want which is technically correct, so we will not oppose these amendments.

The amendments before the chair have been explained by the minister as dealing with a flexibility of accounting periods and an ability for the tax office to recognise commercial practice and, by special determination, vary tax periods on request. Conceptually, that is a worthwhile change and one that we are not opposed to. However, I seek clarification on one point, and it is a question to the minister. I think it is clear in the amendments, but when the minister explained his amendments to us I did not hear him say that that is all subject to the acceptance by the Commissioner of Taxation of those changes.

As I read these amendments they provide what you suggested they do provide—that is, flexibility to recognise commercial accounting periods—but it is not flexibility of right. As I read them, it is flexibility subject to the attitude of the tax commissioner. It is clear from the text, but I do seek from the government an acknowledgment that that is a proper interpretation.

talk.start.para: —The commissioner must be satisfied that the conditions are in fact met.

—That is how I read it, too. Thank you for that clarification. My second question concerns the three clauses that you are moving as amendments. Your second amendment, clause 27-37 headed `Special determination of tax periods on request', states in subclause (1)(d):

speech.para: any other requirements specified in the regulations are complied with. . .

That refers to tax periods, et cetera. By us accepting that provision without knowing what the regulations will say or when we will see the regulations, is this chamber accepting a discretion blindly with an expectation that the regulations will reflect reasonableness? I ask the minister: when is it likely that the government will be in a position to table the regulations that we are now being asked to accept?

talk.start.para: —Work is already being done on the regulations and the regulations, as is the usual practice, come after the bill is passed. Obviously, the regulations will be subject to review by the Senate in the sense that the Senate has the usual procedure of a disallowance motion if it does not feel that the regulations are fair and reasonable.

—My understanding of the procedure is that the regulations are tabled—as you rightly say—after the bills are carried, but the Senate does not have the power to review the regulations. It only has the power to disallow them. The debate then is, do we accept them or do we reject them as a job lot? I make that distinction because you said `review', which implied a discretion on our part.
—I think I clarified that.

—Yes. I accept your interjection that you clarified it and that my description of `disallowance' is the correct description for the regulations. Can you give us any guidance—since you are inviting us to adopt an amendment which refers to the content of regulations that we have not yet seen—as to what in your view those regulations will contain on this point?

—There is no intention to have any onerous power in those regulations. You and I are in agreement that the regulations are subject to disallowance, but the regulations will allow some flexibility by the commissioner as particular issues arise. I can assure you that it will be done in a way which is not onerous; it will be done in such a way as to give effect to the need for some flexibility in these matters.

—I thank the minister for that explanation. I accept his explanation that it will not be onerous. Given your earlier description that these amendments were minor and technical—the whole 128 of them—and we found amongst that pack some that were not minor but were quite significant, I am not challenging your word that the regulations can be passed off or glossed over easily. I accept your word that the regulations will not be onerous, but I mark the spot for the sake of the record that, if upon viewing the regulations in our judgement that is not the case, we will reserve the right to move a disallowance.

speech.para: This provision deals with a threshold of companies with a $20 million turnover. For the sake of further information on this amendment, is there any indication of how many companies you expect or the tax office anticipates would take advantage of these provisions?

talk.start.para: —I am advised that it is a comparatively small number and probably would be less than 1,000.

—I refer to your third amendment and the insertion, after clause 27-37, of a new clause 27-38 headed, `Revoking special determination of tax periods'. Thereunder are listed three subclauses. A note in smaller print has been helpfully and usefully included under subclauses (1) and (2), drawing attention to the fact that:

speech.para: . . . a determination under this section is a reviewable GST determination (see division 7 of Part VI of the Taxation Administration Act 1953 ).

The fact that the decisions are reviewable highlights the sensitive nature of the discretion that the tax commissioner may exercise at this point. These provisions that you are now proposing to insert in the legislation clothe the tax commissioner with a discretion to make a decision and, if a taxpayer disagrees with that decision, that taxpayer has the ability to then take the tax commissioner to a judicial review under the particular legislation.

I am drawing attention to this because, if the parliament agrees to these amendments—and I have already said we are disposed not to oppose them—we will clothe the tax commissioner with particular powers of making discretionary judgments that may offend taxpayers and if they do offend taxpayers, those taxpayers' only recourse is to a judicial process to overturn the decision of the tax commissioner. What steps, if any, will be required in the regulations or as guidelines for the tax commissioner to consult taxpayers or to consider representations from taxpayers prior to the commissioner making a decision that affects their material wellbeing?

talk.start.para: —That would not normally be laid out in regulation, but it would be normal practice to make sure that taxpayers' views are properly considered. I think that is a general practice which occurs in the taxation area. I am seeking advice as to whether there is any other area where there are regulations of the type that Senator Cook proposed.

speech.para: Having consulted with my advisers, my comment stands that there are areas, as you correctly specified, where a decision by the commissioner is reviewable. The commissioner has a responsibility in all cases to take into consideration the representations he may receive from taxpayers who may be materially affected by his decisions. Certainly, from what I can observe, that happens all the time, so I think we are following normal practice in this regard.

talk.start.para: —In this area, the discretion is about accounting periods, so this is not—dare I say—an obvious area of weighty discretion. It seems to be an obvious area of reasonable discretion. The issue for discretion appears, at least blandly to me, without having a sophisticated understanding of the types of issues that the commissioner might have to weigh, to be a matter that the parliament could reasonably expect the commissioner to do properly in the discharge of his obligations—with the safeguard of a judicial review if he fails to do so.

speech.para: As you would know, Minister, before the Senate Economics References Committee is a reference about the administration of taxation in Australia. That reference proceeded only a short way into its hearing and was then set aside because of the inquiries by the Senate into the 27 GST bills, but one expects it will resume in the near future. In that hearing, as I recall, there were questions of the discretion exercised by the tax commissioner for major taxpayers in Australia where, in one commercial takeover of a major Australian company by a foreign company, there was an allegation that the tax commissioner wrote off upwards of $1 million of tax debt. I am not going into whether or not that is a correct allegation, but I acknowledge that, in my experience, allegations of that sort are made distressingly often. This is not to say that those people who make them are right and it may well be that the tax commissioner is 100 per cent correct in the expression of his judgment.

I am not going into those issues at all, but you would be aware of a Four Corners expose on the functions of the Taxation Office which made allegations of that sort and, in the same program, allegations of criminal involvement and things of that nature. I do not refer to these as if they do not come from a source that can be easily dismissed. They come from a source that, if they are made by that source, has to be engaged and dealt with, I would submit. That is a preamble to my consideration of issues of discretion and the clothing of the commissioner with the discretion to write off major losses or tax debt by large corporations.

The allegation made by the Four Corners program was that, if you are from the big end of town, and particularly if you can engage a major accounting house which may have recruited its senior staff from the tax office by inducing them into the commercial world with much higher salaries and emoluments than they would get in the public sector, you would be able to hook into a network of mates or an old boys club or things of that nature and get access to the decision making processes where discretion could be exercised, in a way in which ordinary taxpayers would not have access to it. As a consequence of a lack of accountability on this basis, things get done that aid the big end of town, a facility which is not available to the small end of town and unavailable to ordinary taxpayers like you and me at all.

Again, I do not go to the truth of that because we have got up a reference which the Senate was, thankfully, prepared to endorse and that is under inquiry by a Senate committee. But I give you that background as essential to our approach to questions of the exercise of discretion by the tax commissioner, the reviewability of those exercises and the public disclosure or transparency about how they should be done. The tax commissioner has an extraordinarily difficult job and I do not envy him his task. While I have considerable reservations about his entry into the GST debate, particularly on the subject of food, which seemed to be his only concern, by and large I have a high regard for the commissioner. He is a person for whom the community must also have a high regard.

Going back to these questions of the exercise of discretion by the tax commissioner, which now arise before us by virtue of the first of 128 amendments from the government, as I understand your answer there will be no expression in the regulations that would be signposts or guidelines for the commissioner in the exercise of his discretion. On what basis, then, do we know what tests he applies, how he judges these things, what appeals there might be or representations acceptable to the tax office when he forms his judgment to exercise that discretion? Can you address us on that point for a moment, please.

talk.start.para: —Senator, there is a range of matters that were raised with you. My advisers have noted the last matter. When I conclude my remarks I will respond to that. I note the concern you raised about the discretion. I take it from the remarks that people, including Senator Murray and Senator Margetts, have made that we all agree that in this case this is a sensible approach. The questions raised by Senator Cook in relation to various aspects of administration are really broader questions which, undoubtedly, the committee that Senator Cook referred to will be looking closely at.

speech.para: In relation to the Four Corners program and the allegations made there, my memory is that the Commissioner of Taxation made a full response to the accusations which were raised there. I note your appreciation of the work of the commissioner. I am sure he will read Hansard, but if he does not I will be meeting him next week and will draw those remarks to his attention.

I think it is probably worth reflecting on the relevant clause of the second amendment that we are making which relates to special determining of tax periods on request. If you read under that clause, essentially the things are quite factual. The commissioner must be satisfied that your annual turnover meets the tax period turnover threshold and that the tax periods specified in the request are consistent with the commercial accounting periods that apply to you. The sorts of issues that Senator Cook raised are far broader than the issues before us here. We are essentially looking at accounting periods and the discretion that the commissioner has. The amendments list the sorts of issues that the commissioner must take into account in coming to his conclusions. If you can bear with me, I will see whether there is any additional material I can bring to your attention.

It is also worth noting, Senator, that the matters that may be in the regulation—you have a particular interest in this, I take it from your questions—are not finalised at this time. Of course the ATO and the Treasury would consult with industry to determine, in relation to the regulations, what type of requirements may be appropriate. So there would be a period of consultation as well. That is the normal practice, as far as I am aware, in these matters and that quite often ensures that when matters are brought before the Senate most of the issues have been well thrashed out now that—as you have said—the Senate has the power to disallow. There will be a sensible period of consultation before the regulations are finalised.

talk.start.para: —Does that mean, after the sensible period of consultation with industry, that the regulations will spell out more detail than you earlier foreshadowed they may do in giving expression to these legislative terms?

—There may be issues which are raised. Until we carry out that consultation, I think we would reserve the right to ensure that, if issues are raised that are relevant to the regulations, they can be included in the regulations. You raised some wider policy issues in relation to taxation matters. You were very careful to indicate that you did not make any claim about the veracity of the examples you raised. You were obviously concerned that some of these issues were raised on Four Corners .

speech.para: I do not think that this area is of that order of magnitude. We are dealing with accounting periods. There are discretions which give the commissioner flexibility. The amendments outline some of the things that the commissioner would obviously take into account. Senator, I take it from your comments that you do not have a huge concern in this regard; you just want to be comfortable that the regulations will not be onerous. As I said, they will not be onerous. There will be a consultative process carried out to make sure that issues that we are not aware of, if they are appropriate to regulations, are included in those regulations.

talk.start.para: —I was very careful to say that, from my understanding, there are no difficulties here, and it appears sensible on the face of it. I have only a plain person's understanding of these matters. I do not have a sophisticated understanding. If I had the ability to see into the minds of tax avoiders, I would be a far better legislator than I am. But I do not have that ability and I do not know to what extent these things may be manipulated by skilled experts who are able to have the discretionary funding to pay accountants to find ways to slip through things. That is the reason for my caution, and it is only for that reason.

speech.para: I will take you up on a couple of final, and hopefully concluding, questions on this point. You are now saying that there will be consultations with unspecified people in order to get the clarity and how it will function clear. The outcome of those consultations may be reflected in regulation. That is my understanding of what you are saying.

Can you tell us by whom the consultations might be conducted? Is this a job for the tax commissioner or the department, or will you as the minister be involved in those consultations? And with whom will they be conducted?

talk.start.para: —Typically, it would be done by Treasury and the tax office. I think this is normal practice. I do not see us varying normal practice. What happens with regulations, where people are unhappy about it, is that they sometimes bring their concerns—pretty quickly, in my experience—to the attention of the minister. At that stage ministers may well start to become involved. Essentially, we would be following usual practice. Officers would be carrying out the consultation.

speech.para: The advice I have got on tax avoidance, which I think was an issue which you raised prior to your comments on consultation, is that there is really no scope here for tax avoidance. This is not one of those things which would lend itself, in the view of the officers who are providing advice to me, to tax avoidance. So if tax avoidance is one of the concerns that you have, I think we can give you some comfort on that matter.

talk.start.para: —Can you tell me with whom the consultations will be conducted?

—The amendment essentially affects large corporate bodies, so it would be with bodies like the tax association. It would be with relevant groups. In my experience, the department has been pretty good about involving relevant groups in consultations. I do not say that I have not received complaints from time to time, but I think it is fairly rare that people feel they have been excluded when they feel they have a view to put. When people feel they have a view to put, the department and the tax office are usually pretty accommodating. We are not seeking to exclude people; we are just seeking to consult with relevant people.

—Given that the threshold test here is companies with a turnover of $20 million a year or more and that there are only, according to your earlier answer, about 100 or so of those that may be affected—
—Less than 1,000.

—So it involves only companies with a turnover of $20 million and there are fewer than 1,000 such companies likely to be affected, and the consultations on the regulations that I have been inquiring about are likely to occur with organisations that represent those companies. Can you give us an assurance that included in those consultations will be representatives of ordinary taxpayers or taxpayer organisations?

speech.para: I ask that question for this reason—and it will be a theme of mine, and I foreshadow it now: where other areas of discretion are to be exercised by the commissioner, I do not think it is desirable to place the commissioner in a position where the only organisations to whom he talks are the organisations affected by the particular regulation or legislative requirement. I think it is also desirable that other taxpayers who are not directly affected—or representatives of taxpayer organisations not directly affected—be party to the consultations as well, so that there is transparency. It guards the tax commissioner against any allegations that there was a cosy deal done here between the commissioner and the heavy hitters which the rest of us did not quite know about or understand the nuances of; and, as a consequence, had we known more about them, may have taken a different view on.

Are you able to give us an assurance that the consultations that are being conducted will not just be with the people affected but with respected organisations or individuals who are expert in the act and who are the voice of other taxpayers, so that there can be an understanding that it does represent a wider view than that of just those immediately affected and that no cosy deals can then be pointed to?

talk.start.para: —From what I can judge from the press in the last year or so, I do not think too many people in corporate Australia think there are cosy deals between themselves and the Commissioner of Taxation. That is not the usual complaint I get. Let me give you this assurance: the commissioner and his officers will seek to consult with all relevant people. We do not seek to exclude people. If people or organisations feel that they can make a contribution, I am sure any requests from those organisations will be received sympathetically by the commissioner. To my knowledge, there are a large number of bodies involved in the taxation area and people who have a particular interest and focus. Quite a few of them would feel they are not hugely resourced. So it is a bit hard to determine which is the typical organisation which may feel that they represent all taxpayers. There are a few which have umbrella-type names.

speech.para: The second issue is whether bodies that may put themselves in that position really feel that they would want to take part in this exercise on this type of regulation. I think a lot of them are pretty tight with their own resources and may not feel that this would be an appropriate way to focus their attention.

We are interested in proper law, in law which is understandable, fair and balanced; we are not interested in cosy deals between the tax commissioner and corporate Australia. As I said, the tax commissioner is not typically criticised on those grounds; in fact, it is the reverse, it seems to me. The best I can give you is the assurance that, if people wish to contribute and feel that they have a case to put, those requests would be received with sympathy by the tax commissioner. There is nothing that we would be doing here and elsewhere which is extraordinary and in any way does not follow normal practice. There are quite a few vehicles for people—the consultation phase, consideration of drafts, representations to government ministers and to shadow ministers and finally the presentation of the material in this chamber—which give plenty of transparency to the development of regulations. Your observations, comments and particular concerns have been noted. I think we can address your concerns but we would want it to be done in a practical manner.

talk.start.para: —Minister, I note that I said, to protect the Commissioner of Taxation from allegations of cosy deals, consultation should be across a wider scope than just the people concerned with that part of it. There are a number of organisations that could be consulted on this matter. If, after being advised that the consultations are open to them, they choose not to exercise that option, that is not something I can do anything about. That is their call and I have to respect that. But they should know about it and have an opportunity to have a say. If the process is proper, at least then if a program—and I do make a judgment, as I have said—like Four Corners makes an allegation of cosy deals with the tax commissioner, there is a process that can be pointed to where all the points were considered about how that discretion should be exercised.

speech.para: However, you have also said that not all of this may be reflected in the regulations. I understand that the tax commissioner has his own operational guidelines as well, which are not reflected in the regulations, and which are tax procedures. Can you give us an undertaking that will go to those guidelines too and that there will be some way in which the parliament can know what those guidelines are?

While this appears on the face to be an unexceptional issue of discretion—and I acknowledge all the things you have said and I have said about that—rather than take up the time of the Senate later when we come to the other more weighty exercise of discretion, it is as well now to make our position clear on this point, given that it is the first occasion that the exercise of discretion issue is before us.

talk.start.para: —The administrative guidelines are not usually brought before the parliament. I have no doubt that, if any senator had a particular interest and wanted to be fully briefed on those operational guidelines, the commissioner would be happy to arrange a briefing. We are not doing anything which is not now public and transparent. These bills will be very closely read by all taxation organisations. They will be very much aware that regulations will be drafted to reflect particular sections of the bill and give effect to them. Those organisations will be reading our debate here and, if they wish to, are invited to make a contribution. Those contributions would obviously be considered by the commissioner and his officers.

—That concludes my questioning but I need to correct the record because I have misled the Senate. I referred to the Four Corners program. My trusty adviser has reminded me that it was not the Four Corners program that made the allegations but that it was the Sunday program on the Nine Network. So I may well have slandered Four Corners and offended the Nine Network. If I have, I apologise, obviously. It was the Sunday program on which the allegations were made and I just make that correction for the record.
—In that case, picking up your error, I may have run with that error myself. We note your comments. The Hansard will show that I too might have misled but that can now be corrected.

speech.para: Amendments agreed to.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move government amendments Nos 4 and 5:

speech.para: (4) Clause 29-40, page 61 (after line 5), after subclause (1), insert:

(1A) However, any charitable institution, any trustee of a charitable fund or any *gift-deductible entity may choose to *account on a cash basis, with effect from the first day of the tax period that the institution, trustee or entity chooses, whether or not its *annual turnover exceeds the *cash accounting turnover threshold.
(5) Clause 29-50, page 63 (after line 12), at the end of the clause, add:
(5) Paragraph (1)(a) and subsection (3) do not apply in relation to any charitable institution, any trustee of a charitable fund or any *gift-deductible entity.

These amendments give charities the option to account for the goods and services tax on a cash basis. Under the goods and services tax, entities may choose to account on a cash basis if their annual turnover is $500,000 or less. Businesses that do not account on a cash basis will generally be able to adopt the same basis for accounting as they use for income tax. However, charitable institutions and gift deductible bodies do not need to account for income tax and they often account for their activities on a cash basis. Amendments Nos 4 and 5 that I have moved will therefore allow all charitable institutions, gift deductible bodies and the trustees of charitable funds the choice of accounting on a cash basis, regardless of their turnover.

talk.start.para: —As Senator Kemp has indicated, this is some movement towards allowing a cash basis for charities so that they can perhaps reduce some of their compliance costs. It allows charities to continue to account on a cash basis and it is good for easing compliance costs in that sense. But it is only a minor step, we believe, towards dealing with the issue of compliance costs for this third sector. The government has allocated a mere $500 million towards helping out small and medium business with their increased compliance cost.

speech.para: Figures extracted from the Australian Bureau of Statistics publications indicate that there are 899,700 small businesses and 26,800 medium sized businesses, making a total of 926,500 businesses for whom the $500 million start-up costs were intended in the new tax plan. On average, each small or medium business will benefit, to the extent of $540, for start-up costs. That does not include any ongoing costs associated with the collec tion of tax. We have heard the government saying again and again during the committee stage that there will be a compensation package but let us put that in perspective. We are talking here about an average of $540 per business.

Since the original announcement, the government have said that this will have to be spread between small and medium businesses and charities and other not-for-profits. Remember, during the committee stage every time we brought up compliance they said, `Yes, but there is a generous package to assist with that.' We are having to stretch that even further so that will make that $540 less than $540. On the face of it, it seems that this will not even be enough to purchase the software, let alone pay for potential new computer hardware that may be required to do the extra accounting work or to pay for someone to do that extra accounting work. So that $540 is not going to go very far at all.

Before I move the Greens amendments Nos 1 to 3 on sheet 1381 to this amendment, I have a number of questions for the government which may assist in determining the adequacy of the sum of $500 million set aside to help small and medium business—and the education, health, charitable and non-profit sectors—with the start-up costs covering computer software and hardware. Firstly, how many small and medium businesses were targeted for assistance in the new tax plan with this sum of $500 million?

talk.start.para: —I am not clear as to what precisely this has to do with the bill before us. A mechanism has been put up—an advisory committee of small business has been established—to look closely at how the funds that are being distributed can be best applied. My understanding is that at present their considerations are still under way. They have not made recommendations to the government. We look forward to receiving the recommendations from those groups to determine how the money—which I think is a considerable sum, but perhaps you and I may differ on that—will be distributed and to whom. There is not a date for reporting on this but I think everyone is aware that it is an important issue. It has been given very serious attention by the government as to how this money will be distributed and to whom.

—Let me explain the direct relevance. Here we have a few bandaid measures to deal with those people who might not be caught in the $500 million. These questions are directly relevant because we have to ascertain what their real need might be and what might potentially be coming their way. What are the criteria for determining whether a business is a small business or a medium sized business?

—I think this is part of the process which the advisory committee is looking at. This amendment gives effect to some of the issues which were raised by charities. It was a measure that they were keen to have. The government was pleased to respond to these concerns. The issue of the $500 million assistance is one which is, in a sense, quite separate from this. It is an issue which has an advisory committee looking closely at it to provide proposals to government as to how the $500 million can be most effectively used. Given that there will be widespread interest in this, I am sure the report will become recommendations and the decisions the government makes will be given very wide currency. Once the government makes some decisions based on the recommendations I am sure there will be huge interest in that. This amendment is simply our response to the issues that some of the charities have raised with us. We think it is a sensible amendment. We think it deals with some of their concerns for the reasons which I stated. I see the issues you have raised on the $500 million as really quite separate from this and the government has an advisory type committee which is looking at the issue and will provide recommendations to the government.

—The nature of my questions will reveal themselves quite soon as to why this is not quite separate from the issue of the bandaids for other groups that are falling outside the loop. You said it is a very gener ous amount, and it sounds like a large amount, but I am just trying to work out in reality how much was intended to be allocated to each small and medium size business for assistance towards start-up costs. So if you have come to this generous amount of $500 million, surely it is based on some calculation of how much it will cost and where that money is going to go—how far it is going to stretch. How much was intended to be allocated to each small and medium size business for assistance towards start-up costs? And has the government obtained any estimates from accountancy or management firms as to the start-up costs of computer software and hardware and training of staff for the average small or medium size business?

—The first part of your question goes to the advice and the recommendations the government will receive from its advisory committee. The government has put together an expert body to consider these issues. They will provide recommendations to the government and then the government will make its decisions. I do not want to pre-empt what they will tell us. As I said, we think it is a very considerable sum of money which has been put aside and we have established an expert committee.

speech.para: In terms of the net cost to business, I think that is stated in the RIS and in the explanatory memorandum. The EM shows that it is approximately $130 per registrant. That is the figure which has developed and has received wide currency. That is the net cost on an ongoing basis—$130 per registrant.

talk.start.para: —I am asking these questions on the response of the government because I remember that Senator Tierney in this chamber was very angry each time groups and members of the committee expressed concerns about the adequacy of the package, and we were very loudly told we should be saying that it is a very generous package and that there is a compensation package. Now you are saying the amount is $130 per registrant. There are at least 92,000 non-profit organisations operating as formal legal entities and as many as 325,000 if the myriad unincorporated associations are included. Has the government obtained any estimates from accountancy or management firms as to the start-up cost to educational institutions, hospitals or other health institutions, other non-profit organisations such as sporting clubs, environmental organisations, overseas organisations and others?

—A lot of people have accountancy systems and the costs of the change for some bodies will be very small. Others may not have systems in place and they will wish to ensure they have proper accounting procedures, so I think it is a bit too simplistic to say you should just provide a specific sum of money to share out amongst a wide group when that may not be the best way to deal with this issue and to use the $500 million which is available. This is why we have an advisory committee to provide us with advice on how best to use that sum. This is before them at the moment and their considerations are under way.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 12.29 p.m. to 1.15 p.m.

talk.start.para: —Before we broke for our luxuriant lunch—
—You should explain that because no-one else will understand.
—Certainly. Before the 45-minute lunch break, we heard from the minister that in terms of small business and medium sized business the government was allocating $130 per registrant.
—No, I didn't say that.
—That is what you did actually say. Perhaps you could clarify that before I move to further questions.
—The estimate of the net ongoing compliance cost was, as set out in the RIS, $130 per registrant.
—You didn't make that clear at all.
—I have some advisers here who listen intently to every word to make sure that there is not a variation from the straight and narrow.
—Plus those Treasury people watching you.
—Senator Sherry is right. The Treasury and tax people are watching very, very closely. Senator, I would be very surprised if the Hansard did not show that.

—I thank the minister, but he will find that the Hansard does not show that. I could not even clearly get the word `registrant' for a while. So $130 per registrant is what the Treasury estimates to be the ongoing compliance cost, but we never got to the determination of the software or the hardware costs. Ongoing compliance costs are $130 per registrant. I think the accountant you could hire for that would be very, very short term.

speech.para: I asked about the 92,000 non-profit organisations and 325,000 potential unincorporated associations. I am given to understand from the minister that the potential cost associated with them were still to be looked into. Has the government determined what part of this $500 million will be allocated to various institutions, organisations and groups? I remind the Senate that, even with the businesses we looked at, we were looking at only $540 being available. Has the government determined what part will be available or allocated to various institutions, organisations and groups, which will leave less for small business and medium business? Has the government determined what number of institutions, organisations and groups will be entitled to assistance under the start-up scheme?

talk.start.para: —This is part of the ongoing consultation which is occurring. We have set up an advisory group to look at how the $500 million can be best distributed. They will be providing advice to the government.

—I interpret that as their not really knowing. Are there any plans to determine the assistance to different types of institutions, organisations and groups? What is the general broad-brush plans to determine that kind of assistance?
—Senator, I simply do not want to pre-empt the work of the committee. This is the sort of work that the committee will be providing recommendations to the government on.

—I thank the minister to a certain extent, but it is far from pre-empting if the whole basis for your argument is that these people will be looked after and you do not actually know if or how they will be looked after. As a result of the lack of clear understanding of the minister, I seek leave to move amendments 1 to 3 together from sheet 1381 revised.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move, also on behalf of Senator Brown:

speech.para: (1) Subclause 29-40(1A), omit "charitable institution, any trustee of a charitable fund or any *gift-deductible entity", substitute "*eligible non-profit organisation".
(2) Subclause 29-40(1A), omit "institution, trustee or entity", substitute "organisation".
(3) Subclause 29-50(5), omit "charitable institution, any trustee of a charitable fund or any *gift-deductible entity", substitute "*eligible non-profit organisation".

What we are hoping to do here is to extend the small concession given to charitable institutions to be able to continue on a cash basis. These amendments extend it to all eligible non-profit organisations.

What we heard in the responses to my series of questions is that there is no information that the minister can give us about the implications of costs for organisations that currently do not fall within small or medium businesses. We do not know whether the minister has any information specifically about what extent of cost there will be to charitable organisations. Basically, what we do know is that the government is acting in the dark on this issue.

Why do we need to move this? We think it is important to remember that the third sector goes far beyond charitable institutions and gift deductible entities. Community organisations are the backbone of society. They play a huge role in supporting and enhancing our communities. When we find further and further cuts to various programs in a whole range of areas—be they in the areas of sport, health or the environment—the role of community organisations becomes more, not less, important. These include a myriad of groups playing a role in welfare, health, education, sport, recreation, child care, entertainment, finance, overseas aid, environmental protection, Aboriginal affairs, emergency services and the organised representation of interests or lobby groups. As I mentioned before, there are at least 92,000 non-profit organisations and as many as 325,000 associations if you include the unincorporated groups. Together they employ 400,000 people—that is, nine per cent of the otherwise private sector work force. That is way above any numbers of people employed in the timber industry in Australia.

talk.start.para: —Or mining.

—Or potentially mining. They spent $15 billion per annum, and that amounts to 3.5 per cent of the gross domestic product. It is also important to remember that many of these organisations have had their funding cut over the last few years. This does not mean they give us better service; it means they have to do with less—and a lot of the time their funding has been cut because they have been prepared to speak up and comment on and respond to government policy.

speech.para: With the GST, this section will face immense compliance costs. Many of these organisations paid no wholesale sales tax and were wholly outside the tax system. Many have limited accounting facilities and personnel, and would currently account on a cash basis. We can also see there being a problem with the government proposing to introduce an artificial distinction between commercial activities and non-commercial activities. It will be difficult to make many of these fine distinctions and, therefore, compliance costs will be increased.

With the proposal to exempt food, the government has made a fuss about the costs associated with working out what is food and what is non-food. Contrast the government's fuss over that issue with the lack of response it is prepared to make for all of those groups, all of those who do not fit into its definition of `charitable institution'. This deserves serious consideration. As I said, my series of questions would indicate that, from the government's point of view, they really are the forgotten sector. I would like to think there will be support from the Labor Party. It was prepared to support amendments from the government on what the government considered to be so-called technical amendments, though we have had an indication that the opposition will not be supporting all government amendments.

Let us assume that this is an unintended consequence in this area. I would not like to think that any government would deliberately put an impost of this nature onto organisations who are not rich in any way, shape or form, who play such an important role in a whole range of areas and who employ so many people—getting on for half a million people in Australia. It is not a small sector by any stretch of the imagination. I would be keen to see a response to that. If the government is about to jump up and say that the problem is in relation to definitions, I would pre-empt it by saying that we are flexible in relation to the definition from page 1328. I will respond to the government if it thinks that is a problem.

talk.start.para: —Senator, we certainly do see your amendments as a problem. The amendments proposed by Senator Margetts would significantly broaden the concession to account on a cash basis to include organisations such as sports clubs, political parties—the Liberal Party, presumably the Labor Party and others—lobbyists, trade unions and professional organisations. Typically, such organisations would account on an accruals rather than a cash basis, I am advised. The intention of the government's proposed amendments is to ease the administrative burden on charities and gift deductible bodies who would be more likely to account on a cash basis—and universities, schools and philanthropic organisations, which I think you have provided in your list, would be covered by that provision.
—Considering there already are definitions in relation to the $500,000, can the minister give us an indication about whether this would be a huge extension of coverage?

—Senator, you have used the words `huge extension'. A wealthy sporting club—for example, the Collingwood Football Club—could come under or fit in with the definition. Many organisations, in effect, running a big business would come under it. Essentially, we see this as a very substantial increase. I have given the example of a political party. The Labor Party, as we all know, is a hugely wealthy organisation and that would come under it. Probably the same amounts do not repose with the Greens.

speech.para: We are speaking now of very large bodies indeed, Senator. The charities about which you have expressed some concern, and I have mentioned some, are already picked up in the definitions that have been provided by the government. But these are very big amendments; they would make a most substantial change to the legislation. For these reasons, the government will not be supporting them.

The government has given special concession to the charitable sector. In fact, in the charity sector, most of the large organisations probably would be on an accruals basis already. Any organisation with less than $500,000 can account on a cash basis.

I think it is important to state—and perhaps this will give you some comfort—that the commissioner has the discretion for larger turnovers having regard to the organisations' accounting practices. This is an extension of an automatic entitlement to some large businesses. If the commissioner can be convinced that the cash accounting arrangement is fair and proper, he has that discretion. But the government cannot support the way in which you have dealt with these amendments; they are very substantial indeed. For these reasons, we will not be supporting the amendments.

talk.start.para: —Minister, what about such things as a not-for-profit organisation—say, a school which has a parent organisation with a school canteen, a tuckshop or something of that nature?
—A school is covered by the common law definition of charity. A school is covered, if that is your concern.
—I am talking about the tuckshop which is actually providing food and which, presumably, would be operating on what would normally be considered a commercial basis.
—I do not think they are necessarily a charity, but they are unlikely to have a turnover of over $500,000, I would have thought.

—Then presumably these amendments would not be a problem. How about a library, a community broadcaster, a community television organisation or a community Internet services provider on a not-for-profit basis?

—Senator, I think for most organisations, again, it is the $500,000 sales limit. It is a pretty substantial limit, I would have thought. Then of course there is a discretion for the commissioner if it is felt that the cash accounting basis is the most appropriate way to go.

—I think the minister is just proving my point—that, in fact, we are just trying to make sure there are not-for-profit organisations which are not currently covered by the current measure and that it would not necessarily involve a huge number of bodies which were not already covered. I am happy to deal with the minister. If the minister wants to knock out `political party', that is fine. If the minister has some suggestions about what would make this less problematic, I am happy to hear those suggestions. The reality is that, so far, you have not expressed a problem with the groups. You are just saying, `Oh, they wouldn't fit into that category,' in which case there would be no problem with you supporting these amendments, provided we amended them in a way that took out any particular groups that you believed should not be in there.
—Senator, I do not want to recap the arguments. Some of the organisations which would be covered in the way you have defined it are big businesses, in effect, with huge turnovers.
—Which ones?

—For example, a sporting club such as the Collingwood Football Club. These are very big businesses by any stretch of the imagination. I draw your attention to subdivision 29-B of the bill, `Accounting on a cash basis'. The `Permission to account on a cash basis' section says:

speech.para: (1) The Commissioner may permit you to *account on a cash basis if:
(a) you apply to the Commissioner in the *approved form for permission to account on a cash basis; and
(b) the Commissioner is satisfied that, having regard to:
(i) the nature and size of the *enterprise that you *carry on; and
(ii) the nature of the accounting system that you use; and
(iii) how you account for income tax purposes; it is appropriate to permit you to account on a cash basis.
There is a fail-safe clause, if you like, which should, in my view, provide you with a high degree of comfort.

talk.start.para: —It does not actually, because basically each of these organisations is going to have to mount a case. There are going to be costs associated with that. We are talking about not-for-profit organisations, and we include in that indigenous organisations and overseas aid organisations, some of which handle quite a lot of money over time and provide services which could be considered to be commercial services. You are saying that you are not happy with who knows what. You are not happy that some groups may be caught in this which might be rich groups. That is a reasonable response, but you are not prepared to see whether this definition can be changed. I believe we will find that there are organisations that will fall through the gap because of the rush and, I would say, the lazy approach from the government. There will be those organisations that are not considered important enough to actually look at specific amendments.

speech.para: Here we are with all these so-called technical amendments involved with business but, when we are talking about real organisations desperately trying to sometimes carry the mantle of what government have left them to do with the community, you are not prepared to look at it. It is just too difficult, or a bit messy. You are not prepared to look at it. This is very symbolic of the way you have handled this whole legislative package. If it is business, especially big business, you say, `Right. Let's do everything we can to the nth degree to not only make sure they do not have extra compliance costs but also give them rebates to make sure they are all happy and okay.' But when it comes to the community you say, `Let's forget them. It's too hard, too difficult. Let's just say that it's not going to be a problem.' Where are they going to get these resources, Minister?

talk.start.para: —Senator, I think we should probably stick to the facts. The amendments we have moved are in response to charities; the amendments we have moved are not in response to big business. When you say that we have paid no attention to these types of organisations, our very amendments do that. Our very amendments are ones which apply to charities; that is the purpose of our amendments. The substance of what you are arguing is not correct. It is obviously particularly not correct in relation to the amendments we have moved in response to some of the concerns of charities. They are our amendments. They are not in response to business concerns; they are in response to the concerns of charities.

speech.para: I have pointed out to you that in subdivision 29-B there is a section which enables people to account on a cash basis. I suspect that most of the organisations you have quoted would have a turnover of less than $500,000, so they are not caught. On the other hand, clearly organisations such as the Essendon Football Club, the Collingwood Football Club and the Carlton Football Club would be included in your definition. We can quote many examples.

We have responded to community concerns. That is why the amendments are before the chamber. Elements of your amendments are already covered in the amendments we have proposed, but we do not plan to extend these concessions to political parties, sporting clubs and a number of other areas which you have put in.

talk.start.para: —This is very indicative of the government. They do not understand the difference, or maybe they are pretending that they do not understand the difference, between charities and the community sector. The reality is that there are many services—and many are needed these days in the community—by not-for-profit organisations which are not classified as charities. We are getting a very 19th century idea that you make the rich richer and that you simply provide some incentives for charities and everything will be okay. Well, it won't, Minister. Unfortunately, it seems the government have dug their heels in.

speech.para: I would be interested to see if there are other responses from other people in the chamber. I think it is a rather indicative response of the government. They do not actually understand that charities do not cover the definitions of many non-government organisations and community organisations. It is part of a very old ideological image: you make the rich richer, there will be a trickle down, and anybody who gets hurt will somehow get picked up by charitable bodies. I think that is disgraceful.

talk.start.para: —I am concerned in this debate by what I regard as a very well-intentioned move by the Greens (WA) but a difficulty in under standing the consequences from the point of view of tax administration and the organisations which the two of you have been discussing. Turning to Senator Brown's amendments on sheet 1328, under item 5 he has offered a definition of eligible non-profit organisations, which I know the amendments before us relate to.

speech.para: Minister, what I know of income tax law is that over decades the definition of charitable and non-profit organisations has been carefully developed in law and has been reinforced through rulings, convention and so forth. So now, as it were, the entire non-profit organisations and the charitable world are very clear about where they stand in relation to tax law, as is the tax commissioner and tax accountants. In other words, it is a very well-understood area of operation and there is little difficulty. It seems to me that the new definition would break open a new discussion as to what falls in and out and what the consequences will be.

I was very distressed to hear the minister picking on Collingwood, because they are having a bad enough run as it is—being a one-eyed Eagle supporter, at the moment I feel on the up. The point you made is a good one and so is the definition, as I understood it, put forward by Senator Brown. Quite frankly, with the best of intentions—this is not mischievous—this is designed to throw a wider net, but I do not understand what the consequences of it will be. That is what concerns me. I cannot clearly get a grip on it. The Democrats have attempted in our amendments to section 38 to deal with the definitional problem in our own way, and we will come to that discussion later. Of course we think that is a good outcome.

Minister, in Senator Brown's amendment there is a list of definitions from (a) to (p). I doubt if you will be able to advise me because I would not be able to, but I wonder if your advisers would be familiar with which of those already fall properly within the definitions of charitable organisations and which do not—there are 16 listed there—so that we can understand where the problems are within the 16 and the range of difficulties which you have been trying to outline in your response to Senator Margetts's questions.

talk.start.para: —I can provide you within minutes, maybe even sooner, some preliminary advice. It is being done on the run, but we will give you an indication. What is a charity has been an issue for a long time—there have been a lot of cases on this. The definition is pretty broad. At common law, charities are generally organisations that are established for the advancement of education, the relief of poverty, the advancement of religion or other purposes beneficial to the community. We believe the definition is very broad and further extended in this case by organisations that are tax deductible. In a sense, we have extended it as well from charities. We simply do not want to cover organisations such as sporting clubs and political parties. A lot of organisations will be under the turnover limit and therefore they will not be affected by this.

speech.para: This is preliminary advice—and I stress that this was done on the run. We would not want you to hold us to this. The advice I have is: (a) is covered, (b) is covered, (c) is covered, (d) is not covered. We would have to check further on organisations under (e). Some may be regarded as charities and some may not, or some may be gift deductible. An environment organisation, (f), is covered. It has to meet the relevant criteria, we understand.

talk.start.para: —You are going a bit fast. Did you say that (f) was covered?

—Yes—I have actually got the only copy here—(f) is covered if it comes under the gift deductible criteria. An overseas aid organisation is covered. A political party is not. A trade union or a professional organisation is not. An indigenous organisation—it depends on the nature of the organisation—may or may not be. Obviously, (k) is covered. And (i) and (m) are covered. For a philanthropic organisation, I think the answer is that some may well be and some may not—it depends on the exact nature of the organisation. And (o) and (p) are not covered. So—a point I made earlier when we started off this debate—a substantial section of what Senator Margetts asked about is already covered. A lot of the organisations would be under the relevant limit to register, so those particular bodies would not be affected.

speech.para: But when you get into bodies like sporting clubs and other things, you are suddenly changing—to slightly mix a metaphor—the name of the game. We think that we have moved to cover an issue which the charities raised with us. We certainly do not wish to go further in the way that you have pointed out. As I said, the other thing that is worth pointing out is that where there is a real cash basis issue there is a subdivision—29-B—in the legislation which is before us under which an organisation can make representations to the tax commissioner.

talk.start.para: —Minister, thank you for that. That was actually very helpful. I will just give you a quick check back of your preliminary advice, and I accept that it is preliminary and on the run. Of the 16 items listed, eight you gave a tick to, two had a tick and a cross—some parts were in, and some parts were out—five were out and one you were not sure on and would need to check on.

speech.para: The point that I then want to explore is that for those that are in there is little problem. There is tax precedent, tax ruling, common law, definitions established, and so on. For the remainder that are not in, I would assume it would then be necessary in terms of this legislation to add them to the dictionary of definitions. Is that right? Because if it was the intention of the parliament to put in, for example, a political party you would have to define what that meant, I would guess. Or if it was a trade union or a professional organisation, you would have to define what that meant. Because, otherwise, I assume you have to go through the whole process of common law development, rulings, definitions and all those sorts of things over time. Is that right?

talk.start.para: —If you wanted to give effect to some of these things, my advice is that you would have to have a lot of amendments which would describe the nature of the body. This would not be the way to go. You would have to define what is a political party and what is a sporting club. For example, is chess a sporting club? There is quite a wide range of issues which are involved there. As I have said, we have given a concession to charities. We have listened to charities, and that also includes tax deductible bodies. I do not think we can go further than that. I think if the parliament wanted to move down this road we would have to have a far wider range of amendments to deal properly with it.

—Minister, could you just recap for us the flexibilities that you believe are already in the legislation? So that you understand what I am talking about, I assume the flexibilities that are there and are established both in the bill and in your amendment are flexibilities relating to methods of accounting, to accounting periods, to threshold levels in terms of turnover and amounts of income received, to activity—in other words, the kinds of activities which generate GST status—or to others.

speech.para: The points Senator Margetts made about the number of people who are involved in these not-for-profit organisations, the size relative to GDP, et cetera, were very strong. The government is as well aware as we are of the importance of this sector. But my assumption so far—and I welcome your response—is that the majority of those organisations, employees and turnover, if you want to call it that, relative to GDP are covered within the legislation. That is my understanding. As you know, we think it needs to be extended a little further, and we will be addressing that later, but I am not too sure that there are major problems emerging at this stage in terms of limitations.

talk.start.para: —The best reference in the bill is section 29-B, which sets out the criteria in section 29-45. It states:

para.inline: 29-45 Permission to account on a cash basis

speech.para: (1) The Commissioner may permit you to *account on a cash basis if:
(a) you apply to the Commissioner in the *approved form for permission to account a cash basis; and
(b) the Commissioner is satisfied that, having regard to:
(i) the nature and size of the *enterprise that you *carry on; and
(ii) the nature of the accounting system that you use; and
(iii) how you account for income tax purposes;

(2) The Commissioner must notify you in writing of any decision he or she makes in relation to you under this section. If the Commissioner decides to permit you to *account on a cash basis, the notice must specify the date of effect of your permission.

You might say we do have a fail-safe clause in the bill. But, as I said, to move in the direction that Senator Margetts wants us to move, we would have to have a far wider range of amendments to properly give effect to that. That is certainly the advice I have received.

talk.start.para: —I thank the minister as well. If it is such a fail-safe mechanism, why has it been necessary for the government to include the category of charities? `Eligible non-profit organisation' does not necessarily mean that we believe all of these are charities but, if the mechanism for people being able to argue their case is so fail-safe, why has it been necessary for the government to specify charities? Does this not actually mean that the interpretation by the tax office may be narrower than what it was when you first drafted the bill?

—As I said earlier on, the definition is broad and, as Senator Murray pointed out to us, there have been many cases which the common law has developed on this. I have read out the criteria. If Senator Margetts would like, we will carry out a more detailed analysis of the list that she has provided and I will report back to the Senate when the debate next occurs. We could provide that to her and Senator Murray, who has a particular interest in this, so we can look more closely at some of these issues she has raised.

—I am not too keen on this sort of process I am about to suggest, but I would like to test it with the minister. It seems to me that one of the problems with Senator Margetts's amendment is that she seeks to substitute something with which we are comfortable with something of which we are not certain as to its total meaning and so on. It seems to me possible to simply add to your statement, however, `any charitable institution, any trustee or charitable fund, any gift deductible entity' or `any eligible non-profit organisation'. The difficulty we would then face is that `eligible non-profit organisation' has not been defined, as I see it—I have looked in the dictionary—by the government.

speech.para: But it would provide you the opportunity, if you wished, either to put in the dictionary definition at a later date that an eligible non-profit organisation is such that the government or the tax commissioner may determine—that does not restrict it because we already have the other definitions—or to revisit and reassess that amendment, as you have offered, when Senator Brown's amendment comes up relative to that. The difficulty that I am expressing to you is the substitution principle. I like what you have and I want to support it, but I also recognise Senator Margetts's concerns—and Senator Margetts's concerns attach to a definition which in turn worries me.
