talk.start.para: —I thank the minister for his offering to provide further information. I will happily accept that. I wonder if at the same time the minister may be able to provide us with an indication of how many entities in each of those categories are eligible for gift deductible status.

—Senator, I am not sure that that will be possible. Certainly the initial response from the advisers is that it would be unlikely that we could provide that detail, but we will take the question on notice. If there is some way that we can give you an indication when I respond, that will assist. We are trying to be helpful; we are not trying to resist the issue you raise, although we do not agree with it. You have asked a question and we will take that on notice and see what we can do.

speech.para: I agree with a certain proportion of Senator Murray's comments, as I understood them. The charitable organisations and gift deductible bodies are well understood for tax purposes. They are well appreciated, and we rely on well-established principles of organisations that satisfy the charitable aims, which I read out earlier on. As I said, we do not support the amendments, but you have asked me some particular questions and I will provide you with the answers. Some of that detail may not be possible, but we will give it our best shot.

talk.start.para: —I have stood out of this debate until this point because I think it is essential that the government state the reasons for its amendments and the Greens explain the reasons for their amendments to the government's amendments and the chamber satisfy itself with those meanings. That point seems to have been arrived at, and it is, therefore, appropriate for the Labor Party, the opposition here, to state our position with respect to all of these amendments.

speech.para: Firstly, we are dealing with the second set of government amendments on sheet FA209. We have dealt with three government amendments so far. This is the second set, and they constitute two changes. That means that there are only 123 government amendments to go after these two to the GST legislation that the government rushed through the House of Representatives and required before Christmas and to which it has now projected 128 further amendments.

I stated earlier the opposition's attitude to government amendments. Briefly, let me recap it. By and large, where those amendments are technical or mechanical in nature, better express the intent, remove ambiguity or close off loopholes, as the government sees it, in its own legislation, we will not oppose those amendments. Our refusal to oppose those amendments should not and cannot be read as support, though, for the legislation. The Labor Party is firm. We are opposed to the GST; ergo we are opposed to the legislation that imposes the GST. But, if a government which has messed up its legislation and now wants to amend it needs an opportunity to get it right, we will concede that opportunity to the government to get its own legislation right. We will not oppose it in that.

However, among the 128 amendments are a number of amendments that we regard as not machinery, as not technical, as having implications far beyond simply better expression and greater efficiency of the provisions of the bill. One of those, which I will not delay the committee on now, is the amendment the government slipped into the pack on casinos. We regard that as having far-reaching consequences, and at the appropriate time we will oppose the government amendment.

Having said that, I now turn to the amendments to these provisions that have been put forward by the Greens. I acknowledge what the Greens are attempting to do. I am not sure that the Democrats support them in this intent, have a reserve position or will oppose them in this intent, given the nature of the final discussion. It seems to me, if I interpret the body language, if not the words of the debate, that you may well at this point be struggling a little, Senator Margetts. But that is for the chamber to decide, if we divide on this issue.

This is the first occasion in the committee stage of this legislation that amendments by the Greens, an Independent or the Australian Democrats have come forward to the first of the 27 GST bills that we have under consideration now. Because it is the first occasion on which minor party or Independent senator amendments have come forward, I would like to take the opportunity just for a moment to state what will be the guiding principles of the Labor opposition in voting on Independent senator or minor party amendments to this legislation. I do so in the expectation that this explanation will clarify the situation and remove the possibility that the Labor Party's attitude can be misinterpreted or misrepresented. I do not for one moment think that that would be the case by the minor parties, I might say, but I do think it could possibly be the case by the government. I have a bone to pick with them, which I have done to some extent thus far and will continue to do at the appropriate opportunities, on where they have misrepresented the Labor Party position.

That is not the matter for debate right now. I want to now go to what will be the guiding principles in dealing with minor party amendments in the committee stage. There are roughly 200 minor party amendments. We have before us almost 350 amendments to the 27 bills to consider. Our position in dealing with those amendments relates to our basic principles about a GST. A GST is a regressive tax. That means that middle and low income earners pay proportionately a higher percentage of their incomes than wealthy Australians, and that is therefore unfair. The government recognises that and has announced a compensation package. We believe that you cannot humanise or make fair the GST. We believe that it is a leap of credibility to believe the alleged lock-in mechanism will prevent the 10 per cent ever rising to 12, 15 or 20 per cent, as has happened in every other country in the world. It is a leap of logic to imagine that that will not happen in Australia were this legislation to come into force.

Even if you believed that the 10 per cent would remain constant, there is no way in the wide world that the compensation that the government has announced to offset the inequity of a regressive tax can remain constant. There is no lock-in mechanism to make sure that the compensation remains as long as a GST remains. Let us look at the international evidence, most recently in New Zealand. Shortly after their GST came into force the compensation was significantly changed by the government. They argued that they had simply reshuffled it but, because the level of cost was much less than it was previously, I do not think they could fairly argue that they had not reduced it. They certainly did. But governments come and go and, as long as this tax remains, the compensation should offset it. There is absolutely no guarantee about that. For those reasons, we are opposed to a GST. We remain firm in that conviction and we will see the argument through on that basis.

As a consequence of that conviction, it therefore automatically follows in logic that, if the principle is wrong, amendments or changes which soften the principle do not remove the basic fault. The principle is wrong; it is only a question of degree about how wrong it is according to the amendments that you make. But, even if you soften it a smidgin here, a tad there or a smaller bit somewhere else, the basic thing remains constant, that this is a regressive tax, that there are no guarantees about its rate in the future and that there are no guarantees that the compensation will remain and the only way you can deal with it is to reject it. As a consequence, we will not be supporting the amendments by the Greens and the Democrats and we will be voting against those amendments. In declaring our position of principle, I do not imply a lack of respect for the honesty of the motives of the movers of those amendments. They may well believe, for all I know, that you can humanise a GST. I think in logic that is not the case. But, if they hold that view, I respect their view and do not attack their motives for holding it. But that is not a reason why we should change on principle, and we will not.

This legislation should not pass. If, as a consequence of our position, at the end of the committee stage of this legislation the government has before the chamber the perfect version of the GST that it wants, I would call upon this chamber to reject that package in its entirety and at that particular point there would be absolutely no doubt where the Labor Party would stand. The Labor Party will stand in direct opposition to the legislation at the end of the committee stage and will call upon this chamber to muster a majority vote to defeat it—to reject this bill and send it back to its makers, never to be seen in the legislatures of Australia again—on the basis that we stand for fairness and you cannot make a GST fair. That is the basic guiding situation for the Labor Party.

This is the first occasion on which amendments have come forward which, I acknowledge, would make it easier were a GST to apply. But that would, and I conclude on this point, be delusionary because we will perhaps soften the GST but we will not remove the injustice of the GST—ever. It is the fundamental question that we are concerned about, and for those reasons we will be voting against the amendments.

talk.start.para: —I am wondering whether we should preface some of our amendments by saying these are purely technical amendments. I just find the logic in what Senator Cook has said a little hard to understand. He will support the government's amendments for their package but will not support amendments which to an extent, if the Senate passes them and the coalition rejects them, are intended—certainly from the point of view of the Greens (WA)—to point out the problems. We can understand the responses in relation to things like a definition—what the problems might still be—but we are trying to point out that there are so many problems and that many of them are in fact unfixable by a quick amendment. I know that sounds like an anomaly, but the point of running these amendments is to show what the problems are, and I am a bit sad that in a way we are being brushed off in that sense by the opposition.

speech.para: Yes, it is probably true that there are not any little fix-it amendments which will make this a fair package. But I think it is necessary, by way of amendment or attempted amendment, to show where those problems exist or to try to tease out where those problems exist. If nobody was running those amendments, people would simply get a very simplified argument from either side as to what is and is not in this package. At least in this process anyone who is following the debate will at least get an idea of what the raft of problems are and note the very fact that the government might be unprepared to deal with it. At least we will get an idea of what problems the government is prepared to deal with and what problems the government is not.

In the cases of those organisations which slip through the fingers, whose sales are in such small quantities that they do not get the benefits of any government schemes for rebate, I really feel that there will be some which will have to take the effort of arguing a case, and that is a money effort as well. That will be an ongoing concern in this process and, unfortunately, I think we are going to get a pattern of who are the winners and who are the losers as a result, and putting the amendments will help to show who the winners and losers are throughout this process.

talk.start.para: —As I understand the logic of Senator Cook's position, it is as follows. You are going to oppose a GST, you are going to oppose amendments to improve the GST and, if the GST goes through, we are all going to have to wear any deficiencies in it. That is a bit like saying, `Listen, everybody, you're all going to die but we're going to make sure you die painfully,' and that is a little uncomfortable to live with, I must say.

speech.para: Turning back to Senator Margetts's amendments, the Australian Democrats have a view that the contribution made by charities and public benevolent institutions in all sectors of Australian life—particularly for the disadvantaged and the poor—is absolutely invaluable. The charitable sector performs work at a cost benefit level which is highly productive and it is work which would otherwise need to be undertaken by the government. In a government sense, it saves substantial sums every year. The GST, as it is proposed to be introduced, will harm the charity sector. Improved or not, it will harm it. It will harm it because it will result in an increased compliance cost and increased administration and therefore it is the job of the government and of the Senate to ameliorate that additional cost as far as possible.

Senator Margetts, as this debate has progressed and as I think I have intimated beforehand, there are really two areas in which I would have preferred your amendments to have been expressed. The first is that I believe you should not have been substituting `charitable institution, any trustee of a charitable fund or any gift-deductible entity' for the words `eligible non-profit organisation' but that you should have been adding to them. I believe it should have read `any charitable institution, any trustee of a charitable fund or any gift-deductible entity or any other eligible non-profit organisation'. That would have met the government's needs, which I think are properly expressed, and would have met yours. We then move on to the second problem, and that is the lack of a definition for `any other eligible non-profit organisation' which Senator Brown—but I presume with your support, Senator Margetts—has attempted to outline on sheet No. 1328.

That definition gives the Democrats real concerns. We do think the definition should be widened, but there are so many potential problems within that. I would suggest, Senator Margetts, that there is time before we reach sheet 1328 for that potential definition to be revisited and reorganised. Whilst the Australian Democrats support your intent, we do believe you should widen the appropriate definitions to support the charitable and community organisations sector as broadly as possible on a straightforward public benefit basis. Nevertheless, I think your solution does not meet your objective, so regrettably I cannot support it at this stage.

talk.start.para: —I am reluctant to rise again, having stated my position, but, reasonably, the Greens and now the Democrats have raised some questions about it and I think it appropriate for me very briefly to reply, although I do apprehend that this part of the debate is grinding to a conclusion and probably the next speaker in line will be Senator Margetts replying to Senator Murray as to whether the changes being suggested are worth while.

speech.para: I do not want to delay unduly on this, but I do appreciate the comments by Senator Margetts that nothing in what I have said runs against the prospect of minor parties raising matters to draw attention to the deficiencies in this bill. Earlier this morning I asked the government, `Would you produce your further amendments? You have produced 128 of them. We believe, in reading these 27 bills, that there are many more technical amendments to come because there are a lot more devils in the detail that you have not yet uncovered. When you do, you will be back into this chamber either after the passage of this legislation—if it goes through—or before this debate is over, with further amendments on technicalities.'

This is a complex set of legislation. We think there are still more problems that the government needs to address. I agree with you that it is appropriate to draw attention to some of those faults on the way through, but, in drawing attention to them, we say that if the government accepts your changes we will not oppose them, but it is for the government to make this legislation in its image—as the legislation it wants.

On the question raised by you and Senator Murray about our stand on principle, Senator Murray said, `It's like we're all going to die and therefore the Labor Party will make sure we die most uncomfortably.' Therein lies the very basis of our opposition, because your illusion, Senator Murray, goes to the fact that we are all going to die.
Senator Murray interjecting—

talk.start.para: —That is what you said, `We're all going to die, and therefore the Labor Party will make us die most uncomfortably.' I object to us all dying. I think we should not all die; I think we should all live, and that is why this legislation should be rejected. The way I prefer to depict our position is to say that this legislation sentences all to hang, and the amendments that you are proposing commutes the death sentence to life imprisonment. I do not think we should be in gaol at all, nor do I think middle and low income earners in this country should be convicted of having to pay a higher proportion of their income in tax than wealthy Australians—it goes to the fundamental question of fairness—nor do I think that the government should dangle a pot of money in front of taxpayers' eyes and say, `Look at the tax cuts we're going to give you,' which we know will erode, in order to buy enough marginal voters to impose a tax that will go on forever and that will eventually penalise them. I am not going to fall for the fistful of dollars. We saw that before, and we have seen it in the past many times where you have tried to buy votes in order to impose a measure that is regressive and runs against the interests of the community.

speech.para: Our fundamental proposition—I only say it in reply to the point that you have raised—is that if the illusion that you put forward depicting our situation is that `We're all going to die. The Labor Party will make sure you die most uncomfortably,' which is my understanding of what you said, then our position is that we should not die at all, and we are going to stand for life, not death. But the way I prefer to see it and to explain it is that these bills are sentencing low and middle income earners in Australia to the death penalty as far as taxes are concerned, and the amendments would commute that. I do not think we should be in gaol at all. Taxpayers should get a fair shake—a progressive tax system, not a regressive one. I say that in reply.

talk.start.para: —All this talk of death and dying! I would like to acknowledge Senator Murray's comments in relation to the wording of our amendments 1, 2 and 3 on sheet 1381, and I would also like to acknowledge that that probably would have been our intent. As I guess were most people, we were drafting amendments quickly. I would be happy to make those changes if I thought there was any chance of getting this amendment up, but I can see we would be whistling into the wind on this occasion unless with the change of wording on amendments 1, 2 and 3 the government would suddenly become happy with them. I see Senator Kemp is not nodding his head, so the reality is that yes, we would be prepared to change the wording but it looks like we would be whistling into the wind. I can read the numbers on this issue.

—I must briefly respond to some of the remarks made by Senator Cook. I am well aware of the passion with which Senator Cook and his party oppose the GST. I have been in proximity with Senator Cook on the select committee on tax for some months, and I am well acquainted with those views. I would remind you that the Greens (WA) and the Australian Greens are also as passionately opposed to the GST, but they have chosen to put up amendments to the legislation to improve those areas which they think deserve such attention.

speech.para: The reason they have done so, Senator Cook, is that neither you nor I nor Senator Margetts can guarantee that the legislation will not go through, because it might go through. If it does go through you know that we will vote against it if food is not made GST free. You know that Senator Margetts and Senator Brown are going to vote against the bill at the end of the debate. But if it does go through anyway and you have failed to exercise your responsibility to make things a bit better, it is my belief that you as a party will have failed to deliver better outcomes than otherwise might have occurred.

I understand—because I have heard you say so—why you have made the choice you have. But that is what lies behind my remark. Even if it turned out that you and your party, Senator Margetts and her colleague and me and my colleagues voted against the GST and it went through, I would be proud if at least I had been able to improve it on the way. That saves people harm; it saves people time; it saves people cost; and it saves people difficulties. Of course, we are now talking about the charitable institutions and I would be very surprised if they are not dear to your heart given the nature of the Labor Party commitment to that sector. So that is what lies behind my remarks. I think it is the duty of the Senate, whatever the legislation, to attempt to amend it. It never ever stops you at the end of the process from voting against the bill. That is exactly what we did with Wik. We tried to amend it all the way through and we achieved some amendments which improved the bill, but at the end we voted against it because we did not think it was good enough. Frankly, I would have much preferred the Labor Party, with its tradition of defending its patch, to have indeed adopted that position. I close my remarks on that basis.

talk.start.para: —The question is that the amendments moved by Senator Margetts and the Australian Greens to the government amendments be agreed to.
—The question now is that government amendments Nos 4 and 5 be agreed to.
—by leave—I move government amendments Nos 6 and 7:

speech.para: (6) Clause 29-99, page 65 (after table item 1), insert:
(7) Page 194 (after line 22), after clause 126-32, insert:

para.inline: 126-33 Tax invoices not required for gambling supplies

speech.para: (1) You are not required to issue a *tax invoice for a *taxable supply that you make that is solely a *gambling supply.
(2) This section has effect despite section 29-70 (which is about the requirement to issue tax invoices).

These amendments involve the issue of tax invoices and gambling supplies. The GST treatment of gambling is to apply GST to the gambling margin, being the difference between the bets received and the total monetary prizes paid out. As a GST is not charged on individual bets, a gambling supply cannot give rise to an input tax credit. As the purpose of a tax invoice is to evidence the GST that can be claimed, an input tax credit is not necessary to require that a tax invoice be issued for gambling supplies. Amendments Nos (6) and (7) remove the requirement for a tax invoice for gambling supplies.

talk.start.para: —These are the first amendments that the government proposes to make to its own legislation which deals with gambling. As we learned from a statement made by the minister to the chamber yesterday, there are of course other amendments. They are the Crown Casino amendments; the amendments that favour high rollers—amendments which have been extensively covered in the media.

speech.para: I have a couple of questions on the amendments on gambling as a group that I would like to put to the minister. Firstly, Minister, last night you had the distinction of appearing on the 7.30 Report in an interview with the moderator of that program, Kerry O'Brien. In that program he put to you these questions:

Following your reply, which I might say was incomprehensible to me, he then asked you:

Following your reply, which was incomprehensible to me, he then asked:
Does the amendment save the casinos money?

talk.start.para: —Senator Cook, I am sorry you did not read the transcript. I suppose we can all be abusive if we want to, but I never am of course.

speech.para: Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

talk.start.para: —As is well known, Senator Ray, I am never abusive; I always play it straight and never play the man. The issue that Senator Cook raised is why we have put these amendments before the chamber.

speech.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Cook asked me why we are making these changes in relation to gambling amendments. I am saying that, in relation to the gambling margin, what we have done is to give effect to the policy that we went to the election on.

speech.para: It is not a change in policy; I have stated that before. It is not a concession for high rollers. The basic point is that the GST is a value added tax. The value added amount for the gambling operator is their margin, and the margin is the bets placed minus any payouts that must be made to the gambler. This amendment is not currently before us, but Senator Cook referred to the package of amendments. I think that, since Senator Cook is determined to have this debate about an amendment which is not actually before the chair, I will assist Senator Cook. But I record that this is, in fact, not the amendment which is before the chair.

We have given effect to the policy with which we went to the election. It is not the Crown Casino amendment. It is an amendment which is perfectly appropriate, perfectly proper. It was brought to our attention by the industry association that the legislation as drafted did not give proper effect to the policy with which we went to the election. Therefore, it was proposed to us by Treasury, following their negotiations with the industry association, that the amendment relating to the margin be made.

That, Senator Cook, is precisely what we have done. The innuendo and disparaging comments that seem to carry forth from that side of the chamber every time this is discussed seem to me, I have to say, to be quite unseemly, not accurate and often defamatory of the individuals involved.

You asked me the net effect of these amendments. You will have noticed that I said last night that there is an agreement with the states that there is to be no net revenue collected from gambling because of the current high level of taxation on gambling and the often legislatively fixed margins. States will reduce their gambling taxes by the same amount as the GST. If the Senate does not pass the amendment—not the amendment actually before the chair, but the amendment relating to the margin—then the states will be required by the intergovernmental agreement to take this into account when setting their taxes. The net effect would be similar, but it would complicate the GST and may cause other administrative problems.

To summarise the position for you, Senator Cook, it was brought to our attention that there was an error in the drafting. An amendment was proposed to the bill which I have brought before this chamber. There is no change in the forward revenue estimates because this gives effect to the policy which everyone assumed was in the bill. But it was brought to our attention that there was an error in drafting. There is no net change in the revenue effect.

What would happen if the amendments on the margin fell over? What would happen if the Senate said no to this? It would be then a matter for the states. But I have pointed out to you the agreement with the states. The states recognise that gambling is heavily taxed, so there is no net increase in revenue collected from gambling because of the current high level of taxation. What would happen then if this amendment did not go through and if the states kept to that principle? I assume they would keep to that principle. The states would presumably, to maintain the appropriate outcome that has been defined, make adjustments to their other taxes. As I said, it is not our preferred course, it is not the way we would prefer to go, but the overall net effect would be similar. If the Senate did not pass the amendment, then the states would presumably have to take this into account when setting their own taxes.

talk.start.para: —By how much? You don't know.
—The net effect would be the same because the states would then presumably have to adjust their tax.
—Give us the amount.
—I don't know. If the net outcome is to be the same—
—Were you given a figure? I bet you were given a figure and you are covering it up.
—Senator Sherry, don't carry on like that.
—How much?
—The net effect would be the same.
—Give us the amount.

—No, I haven't got a figure here. I do not know. What I am telling you is that the net effect would be the same. But it is not our preferred course. It would complicate the GST and may, as I said, cause problems in an administrative sense.

—I don't know that I have the patience of Kerry O'Brien to ask you four times, Minister, but let me ask you again and let me ask you very simply. I use the same question Kerry O'Brien used last night. Your amendments will put money back into the pockets of the casinos, will they not? Can you answer that question?

—Senator, I have pointed out to you that there will be no net revenue gain, so the taxes raised from the casinos via the current state taxes and via the GST will remain the same. If the amendment relating to the margin falls over in this place, the states will then have to adjust their own taxes so the net outcome will be the same. That is the principle. The net outcome will be the same. The bottom line to your question is: what will the states do? What the states will do presumably depends on what the Senate will do, but there will be no net revenue gain.

—I have one quick question. I know that Senator Cook and Senator Ray are keen to ask questions further on this matter. Can the minister please clarify which particular COAG meeting he is talking about? When was this agreement made with the states?
—It was made on 9 April at the Premiers Conference.

—I have a couple of questions for the minister. If it was always the government's intention, why wasn't it in the original legislation? Why wasn't it picked up? Was it only picked up when the Casinos Association drew it to your attention? Was it picked up when someone else lobbied the government that you will not admit to?

speech.para: The second question is: Senator Kemp will not give us a quantity as to how much a GST on high rollers' rebates would be. Has anyone ever given the government those figures, and, if so, why won't you release them?

To follow your point logically through, let us assume that this clause—that we are going to look at at some time and we are talking about a principle now—was to fail, and you could quantify the amount of revenue, which you would have to be able to do in broad terms, what you are saying is that there are no overall revenue implications because the states would reduce their gambling taxes to equate with what comes in through the 10 per cent on the rebated losses of high rollers.

But the implication of that, of course, is that they will not specifically pass on those particular gambling savings to the high rollers. It may well be that they reduce the take from the TAB from 13 per cent to 12 per cent, and that in fact what we will see here is a redistribution of money from the high rollers to the battlers, who are already being taxed very highly. You cannot give many more tax rebates to the high rollers at a state level because those snivelling, crawling individuals have already cut each other's throats to give them the maximum world-wide deal already.

You are really saying that this will be revenue neutral overall, but basically the high rollers will pay tax and the benefits of them paying the tax will be passed on to the battling punters out there. You have given me a really good reason to vote against your amendment.

talk.start.para: —I want to add a question which concerns me and which follows on from questions already outlined. But before I do so, an allegation has been printed in the newspapers which I want to put to rest that the Democrats were completely briefed on this issue and raised no concern.

speech.para: I would point out that there was a briefing to the Democrats in the form of myself and my adviser on the 128 amendments. I arrived late for that briefing and left early because I had other hearings and meetings. My recollection is that the matter was not discussed whilst I was there, and the adviser concerned is available in the chamber. My recollection is that the main discussion we had during that period was concerning the insurance matter, and that, if more than one or two sentences were conveyed to him—according to my adviser—on the gambling amendment, he cannot recall much else.

The effect of a briefing is not that it is a debate. It is not an occasion on which you raise all your concerns. It is to advise what the government means by the amendments and to go away and consider it thereafter. A briefing does not constitute approval, does not constitute a tick-off, does not constitute an agreement and does not constitute a negotiation; it constitutes hearing from the government what their reasons are for putting forward their amendments.

talk.start.para: —You mean you didn't get across 128 amendments in one hour?

—It was 45 minutes. As you know, I was only there for 25 minutes. I wanted to put that to bed early because I know I might be caught by the time. I will return to the fundamental question that concerns me. If I understand correctly, the minister is saying that this is principally a matter of revenue adjustment between the Commonwealth and the states. If that is so, the amendment matters not at all to the casinos. They are not concerned about it, surely. If the casinos are not concerned about it, why should we be concerned about it?
—Why did they make representations about it?

—Why did they make representations about it? If they are not going to make any money out of it, what is their interest in it? If you are telling us that they are not making any money out of it, and it is simply a revenue adjustment between the Commonwealth and the states, then it is not a matter of interest to the Casinos Association, the casinos industry or anyone else.

speech.para: Unfortunately, the only advice I have is in the form of a confidential submission. It seems to me from some of the public statements made in the newspapers and the media that the Casinos Association and the casinos are concerned with the amendment. I do not know of any industry anywhere which is concerned with amending legislation unless it benefits them, and generally speaking financially.

Let me make it clear that I think it is entirely proper for the industry to pursue their self interest. All industries do. What is at issue here is the government's motive and manner of responding to that industry in contrast to the charities, churches, bishops and all the people who are scrambling for the poor, disadvantaged and those who are discriminated against in this package.
To summarise my question and add to those before, if this does not confer a benefit on the casinos, as you seem to be implying, why should the Senate even concern itself with it?

talk.start.para: —You are coming to this matter at a different angle from Senator Ray. Senator Ray, there was a drafting error, because it did not give effect to the policy.
—By whom, A-G's or Treasury?

—I can seek some detail on that, but the legislation that finally emerged clearly did not give effect to the policy with which we went to the election. Therefore, Senator, we want to have the tax paid on the correct margin. Clearly that did not happen with the way the drafting occurred and, in essence, this amendment fixes up a drafting error.

speech.para: What will the states do? Senator Ray said he thought that, if there was going to be no net revenue effect, the states would have to deal with that issue. Presumably, if there is going to be no net revenue effect, the states will have to adjust their taxes accordingly. How they would do that, frankly, is a matter for the states. I am aware—
Senator Conroy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The minister has the call.
—Senator Conroy can make his contribution in the appropriate way.

speech.para: Senator Conroy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I know it seems strange, Senator Conroy, for you to make your contribution in an appropriate way.
—Order!

—What would the states do? I cannot answer that question; I do not know what the states would do. The states would then have to deal with the problem and adjust their taxes accordingly if they are going to keep to the principle of no net revenue effect.

speech.para: Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

talk.start.para: —In order to keep to that principle, the states would have to adjust their taxes. How they would do that, Senator Ray, frankly I do not know; that would be a matter for the states. They would have to turn their mind to this issue.

speech.para: Senator Murray raised the question that, if there is no net revenue effect, why would they bother? They bothered because they came to us and said that the benefit, from their point of view, is an administrative benefit. They see complications, I understand, if we go down the other route and the matter is dealt with at the state rather than the federal level. They see that it is an important administrative arrangement which they feel will more effectively meet their needs and give effect to the promise that the government made at the last election. But if it falls over, it then falls to the states to deal with the problem.

talk.start.para: —How is it revenue neutral?
—Because all the GST revenue, as you know, goes to the states. The states would then, keeping to the principle of—

speech.para: Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Keeping to the principle of no net rise in gambling taxes, the states would then presumably have to make adjustments to their state gambling taxes. Senator Ray asked me what would they do? Senator Ray thought that the states would focus on making sure that, as Senator Ray described it, the battlers would benefit. I do not know what the states would do to be quite frank, Senator Ray—that is entirely a matter for the states. They would then have to work out what they would do.

—Minister, is it not a fact that the states, irrespective of whether this clause gets carried or not, are going to have to alter their gambling tax mix? You are already taxing 10 per cent of winnings and the total amount created there is going to have to be reduced from states taxes. That is almost certainly going to be general practice. So if, in fact, high rollers are taxed more heavily and there is more revenue on this side, they are just going to add it to the formula of reduction, surely. It is not going to create a special problem for them. I do not expect you to know exactly how they are going to handle it; they would not have told you that yet. But that is the logical implication that, just because you have got a bit more in the pot, that is going to go into the generality of the reduction.

—I would also like to ask the minister a question following my question earlier. The minister said that the agreement with the states is that there is to be no net revenue collected from gambling. He said this is part of the agreement with the states. To establish when this longstanding agreement occurred, I asked when did this occur and he said that it was at the 9 April Premiers Conference. So we are talking about three weeks ago. Three weeks ago, in order to get the states on board, the Commonwealth promised this measure: that there would be no net revenue collected from gambling. I assume the reason the states were asking that was that they saw there might be a change. So the states—and some in particular—lobbied the Commonwealth at the Premiers Conference for a change to the legislation.

speech.para: Can the minister also give us an idea of when the meeting or meetings took place between the casino representatives and Treasury officials. How did they relate to this 9 April Premiers Conference buy-off? Because that seems to be what it is—it is not in the ANTS package that anyone on this side can see. On 9 April, there is suddenly agreement between the Commonwealth and the states that there is going to be no net revenue collected from gambling. Which states pressed that at the Premiers Conference? Was it all of them or just some, in the latter case which ones? And, in relation to 9 April, when was the meeting or meetings between the casino representatives and Treasury officials?

talk.start.para: —I would like to hear the answers to all of those questions, but so that you have got all the questions at least at this stage of the inquiry that I would like to have before you, Minister, I would like to ask a couple of others. I have great difficulty with your reply because in this place we all know what a `weasel word' is: that is a word that someone uses to weasel out of an undertaking. You have said in your reply, `I don't know.' You have said in your reply `I presume' and `As far as I'm aware'. It may be that you do not know, it may be that you presume and it may be as far as you are aware, but the purpose of this chamber, unlike television last night, is for us to get at the facts. We do want to know. We do not want to know what the state of your knowledge is. We want to know what the facts are. We do not want to know what you imagine is the case. We want to know what is the case. We do not want to know that you do not know. We want to know what the government has done and what the community is up for. That is why these questions are very important.

speech.para: The second part is that you said the government told us all about this before the election. As far as I am aware, the only publication in which the government did that is this document, which was sent around Australia, Tax Reform: not a new tax, a new tax system. In this document on page 98 there is a section headed `Gambling and lotteries'. I want to read this section and I want you to tell us where in this section it says that the government was going to give high rollers a tax break. This is what it says:

Gambling and lottery activities will be included in the tax base. The GST will apply to the operator's margin of these activities, not to the prizes paid out. That is, the tax will apply to the difference between total `ticket sales' or bets taken by the operator of the gambling or lottery activity and the value of the prizes or winnings paid out. However, operators cannot always adjust their prices because these are often set by the rules of the game or by State government legislation relating to levels of pay-out. As the States already tax gambling highly there may need to be corresponding reductions in State gambling taxes. This will be possible because, under the proposed arrangements, the States will receive the proceeds of the GST, including the GST on gambling.

End of story. That is what you told the Australian people. When did Mr Howard, prior to the election, tell the Australian people that high rollers would get a special tax break? We are talking here about exclusive gamblers who play for the high stakes and wager between $½ million and $5 million a throw. That is the class of gambler we are talking about. This is not someone in off the street. What we are saying here is that it is apparently the practice of the casinos that if a high roller wins they walk away with their winnings but that if a high roller loses, and in those stakes loses heavily, then the casino hands back some of the losses to the high roller so that they do not lose as heavily as they would have done and so, hopefully, they will come back and bet again. That is what we are talking about.

I do not know whether anyone playing the pokies, if they lose, when they go to cash their chips in, is suddenly handed back some of their losses by the casino operator because the casino operator did not want to see them do the weekend rent. But if you are a high roller and you lose the practice is that the casinos hand back some of your losses so that you do not lose as badly, and we are going to give them a tax break in order to enable them to do that.

When did Mr Howard tell us that? Which speech was it? Was it in the policy speech? Was it in a remark he made during the election campaign? When did Australians know that when they voted for this document they were voting for that type of arrangement? It is not clear in these words. In these words it says that gambling is governed by the `rules of the game'. We all know what the rules of the game are. Anyone that has been into a casino knows what the rules of blackjack, keno or poker are. There is no rule that says if you lose you get your losses paid back to you as a rebate. It is not in the rules of the game and it sure as hell is not in any state legislation. So where does it say here that there ought to be a tax break for doing that?

That is the first question. You said it was in the ANTS package. This is the ANTS package I have in my hand. You said we knew about it before the election. When did we learn about it? You said that you are only doing what you told us you were going to do before you got voted back into power. Well, it is not clear to anyone on this side, I can assure you, that you ever made that clear to anyone. And it obviously was not clear to the casino owners either because their association came to see you after they saw your legislation. They said, `Make these changes,' and you did. Why did they do it? According to the explanation that you have just given, there is no benefit in it for them except an administrative efficiency benefit.

I chaired the Senate inquiry into the GST. That inquiry did, as is now popularly known, receive a confidential submission from the casinos. I have not divulged that. I will just say this on the record. I hate receiving a confidential submission from an industry group requesting the Senate to do things in that industry group's interest without the rest of Australia knowing what they want. Therefore I thought it was appropriate that if they wanted something it not be asked for confidentially and secretively. It should be asked for openly and publicly so the rest of us can know what they want. And if they persist in wanting it they should come before our inquiry and answer questions about why they want it. They were not prepared to do that, so we never proceeded. I have not released any copy of their submission either. It does seem, though, that because they made no progress with us they then trotted off to talk to you again and you agreed. Among 128 amendments that you slipped into this pack the other day, all of which were `minor', was this amendment, which is hardly minor at all.

talk.start.para: —Caught red-handed.

—That is right, caught red-handed. You defend yourself in the first part of your answer by saying it is in the document I have in my hand. I put to you, Minister, that it is not in there, it never was intended to be in there, it is a retrospective interpretation by you to justify your current position and it is not true. I put that to you directly. I ask you to show us now where it is supposed to be and what secret words we were supposed to understand it meant. I ask you then to justify how the rest of Australia that voted on this knew that at the time, because on that leg your argument does not stand.

speech.para: I move to the second part of my question. I bear in mind the weasel words that I identified earlier, so please don't include those in the answer. I would much rather, if you do not know, that you tell us that you do not know and promise to undertake to find out for us, rather than say, `I imagine', `I presume', `possibly it was this', `maybe it was that'. Let us get to this honestly, directly and openly. Let us not fiddle around the margins of it.

As I understand your explanation, the states, you presume, will correct any problem that the casinos might see if the Senate rejects the legislation. Senator Margetts has raised this point. She has asked a series of questions which I think are right to the point. When was that agreement reached? Where is it written down? How do we discover it? Which premiers sought it? Why did they argue for it? What is on the public record about it?

I remember seeing on television the other day the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the state premiers after the Premiers Conference. I remember what was said. A lot of what you have said was said was never said. For example, it was never said that the Labor premiers supported the GST. I have been through the transcript. They never said it, but you keep telling us that they did. They never did. When was this deal reached?

The next leg of the question is: if it was reached, and it is on the record and established that it was reached, what obligations have the states entered into? You say that you presume. I do not know what status `presume' has as a legally binding word. I imagine that `presumed' is not a legally binding word. You presumed wrongly. Well, tough luck; it was something else. But what will the states do? Will they amend any legislation?

At the end of the day, we want to be sure of this: if those who bet half a million dollars to $5 million a throw are being subsidised to the effect that if they lose they are handed back some of their losses so that they won't be upset and will come back again as another customer, if that is what the deal is and the states pick up the cost of that, how much revenue do they forgo which would have been spent on hospitals, schools, roads and other services?

This is the federal government; they are the state governments. You can say to us, `Well, it's revenue neutral for us.' But if it just shunts it down the chain to the states and it is not revenue neutral for the states and it is a loss to their revenue, in order to meet the social aspirations of their communities, it has to come from somewhere. If it goes to the high rollers at the casino, who does it come off? I would like to know the answer to that question: who does it come off? Which hospitals don't get started? Which schools got closed down? Which roads never went ahead? Which welfare payments were cut or reduced?

They are questions which go to where this GST debate has now moved to. They go to the fundamental question of fairness. I said in this chamber the other day that that is a good debate to have. That is an Australian debate to have. We are proud of our record of being an egalitarian country; the country of a fair go. But I do not think a fair go can be defined as a payout for high rollers who lose, being shunted down the chain of administration of this country from the federal government to the state government and then being taken out of services to the communities in the states. That is the issue that I think you should now answer, Minister, along with the questions that Senator Margetts has put and the other questions that I have put. I will now give you an opportunity to answer them.

talk.start.para: —I would be delighted to answer that. The first point I would make is that much of your comments are absolute, total humbug. What is the Labor Party's preferred tax system? The wholesale sales tax is your preferred system. When a high roller goes to the casino, how often is the wholesale sales tax applied to him? Is it applied to him when he goes to a restaurant in the casino? There is no Labor wholesale sales tax applied to him.
—It is not applied to food, either.
—I know it is embarrassing. When he stays in a luxury suite, is a Labor Party wholesale sales tax applied?
—A bed tax.
—There is a bed tax in New South Wales, not in Victoria. This is total humbug. We are applying a GST which picks up high rollers.
—Answer the questions.

—I am answering, Senator Faulkner. That is why it is total humbug, because the Labor Party's preferred tax system lets the high rollers off scot-free—scot-free in their restaurants, scot-free in their gambling, scot-free in their accommodation. The wholesale sales tax is not applied, but a GST will be applied. This is total, absolute humbug from you, Senator Cook. You should point out to me how your wholesale sales tax system catches the high rollers. That is the question, Senator Cook, seeing that you have decided to throw yourself all over the chamber in pious fury. Why don't you tell us how your wholesale sales tax applies to these people? The fact is that it does not.
—We wouldn't have cut their state taxes from 40 to 10 per cent.

—Senator Ray has come in because he is embarrassed. It has suddenly occurred to Senator Ray, `Hey, there's a problem here; is the Labor Party being absolutely hypocritical?' The answer is: absolutely, totally hypocritical. You tell me where your preferred tax applies to the high rollers. Because the wholesale sales tax does not apply to services, it does not apply to the high rollers. The Labor Party tax system lets the high rollers off scot-free.
—They pay more tax.

—I will be interested in future contributions from the Labor senators who can explain to me just where their tax system applies to the high rollers. Who is it going to be next—Senator Cook, Senator Faulkner or Senator Robert Ray? The question is: where did this occur? In the ANTS pack age, we set out very clearly that gambling and lottery activities will be included in the tax base. It is not in the Labor Party's wholesale sales tax base by the way; you let them off scot-free. The GST will apply to the operator's margin of these activities, not to the prizes paid out. So the question is: what is the appropriate calculation of the margin?
—Where does it say that?
—That is what we are giving effect to, to establish what is the proper calculation of the margin.
—It says `prizes and winnings'. Losses and rebates are not winnings.

—I know that you are acutely embarrassed by this because you are a supporter of the wholesale sales tax, which does not apply to the high rollers. The high rollers get off scot-free from your wholesale sales tax. When they go into a restaurant at the casino and order lobster and Veuve Cliquot, where is the Labor Party tax?
—You are defending it.

—I am waiting for Senator Faulkner to explain to me carefully where the Labor Party tax system catches this. The answer is: the Labor Party tax system does not. Senator Cook asked me where this was put out in the ANTS package. That is where it was put out.
—It does not say that.
—Senator Cook, with gambling the tax is applied on the margin, and that is precisely what is flagged there.

speech.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my left are bordering on being disorderly and I would like to hear what Senator Kemp has to say.

—Thank you, Madam Temporary Chairman. Then we indicated in the ANTS package that, as the states already tax gambling highly, there may be a need for corresponding reductions in state gambling taxes. This will be possible because under the proposed arrangements the states will receive the proceeds of the GST, including the GST on gambling. That was clearly flagged in the ANTS document.
