Report

talk.start.para: —I present the report of the Select Committee on A New Tax System on the provisions of 12 further bills implementing the proposed new tax system, together with submissions and Hansard record of proceedings.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

This is the third report of the Senate Select Committee on A New Tax System. This report is a carryover of some of the bills that we were not able to consider adequately during the main report into the GST. The bills this report deals with relate to Commonwealth-state financial arrangements, to the luxury car tax bills and to the wine equalisation tax bills. This report represents the final considerations of the Senate select committee on those matters. That Senate select committee will now cease to exist.

The Senate Select Committee on A New Tax System came into being in December of last year. It delivered a significant report on the macro-economic effects of the GST earlier in February. It delivered its main report on a full consideration of the GST, including the considerations by Senate references committees on the community services, the education, employment and industrial relations, and the environment, communications and sports areas, as well as its own considerations after 27 days of sittings. That is the main report. This report means that about 1,000 pages of reports, cumulatively, over the three references, have now been reported by that committee within the space of four months after exhaustive consideration around Australia.

In delivering the main report, I recognised the constructive role played by the secretariat in assisting the inquiry. I also said that lessons had been learnt from the inquiry which would be pursued constructively by me in another way. I can now say that that process has started. One hopes that the lessons we have learnt about how to conduct an inquiry of this magnitude may well be encoded in some changes which will mean that the problems we faced will not occur again. With that in mind, I do know that a number of people in the secretariat have worked extremely hard—in fact, I think all people worked extremely hard and for long hours—and they deserve recognition by the Senate. I formally thank them for that and acknowledge the very fine effort that they have put in.

Going to the detail of the report, the first element of this report concerns Commonwealth-state financial arrangements bills. It only became possible to inquire into these measures after the Premiers Conference, held earlier this month, and when the Commonwealth and the states had finalised their arrangements with each other on how the GST would operate in the states. The first thing I should say about this part of the report is that I believe, and our report reflects this, that substantially the outcome of those proceedings has been misrepresented. It is the government that has done the misrepresenting.

The government has said that state premiers of a Labor persuasion, by accepting a share of revenue that the Commonwealth wishes to give to the states in the event that there is a GST, have somehow endorsed the idea of a GST. That is not true at all. Our report decisively lays that furphy to rest. It does so by no more complex mechanism than simply quoting what the premiers themselves did say, not what the Prime Minister wants us to believe they said. What they said publicly, and to their own parliaments, was that they have reservations and oppositions to a GST, and that they have a general Labor view of a GST: they oppose a GST. Should this parliament, in its wisdom, decide that a GST will apply in this nation, and I hope it does not, the premiers will operate a GST at state level on the basis that the Commonwealth wishes to move to displace some of the state taxes by providing the states with the revenue. That is not an endorsement of the government's position at all. It ought to be made very clear that these state premiers have not endorsed the idea of a GST and Labor is not divided federally or in the states on this matter. Labor is united nationally in its opposition to the principle of a regressive tax.

The second thing that needs to be said is that in these agreements the government has substantially misled the Australian community about the nature of the taxes to be forgone at a state level. It has only become public in the last few weeks that the Commonwealth, based on entreaties by the states—because of the displacement of state taxes and the extra unanticipated costs that the states would therefore have to bear—has agreed to allow one of the taxes that the Prime Minister has claimed will be abolished to continue and be phased out.

The announcements about the benefit in dollars to the states of the deal has been substantially overstated by the Prime Minister. Not all of the taxes that were to be abolished will in fact be abolished immediately, and the alleged benefits to the states are much less than what has been publicly said. I do not have the figures at hand but it is about half of what the Prime Minister has alleged, and that is because one of the state taxes will continue for a time. It is important to have that on the record because at this very early stage of the manoeuvring to convince Australia that a regressive tax is good for you the facts are not being stated accurately and the public debate is being clouded by deceptive comments which do not fully portray the issue. I will not comment on the luxury car tax bills, save to say I draw the Senate's attention to our recommendations on those bills.

I do want to talk for a moment about the wine equalisation tax bills. The inquiry we conducted had considerable evidence before it about the changes in tax arrangements that the Commonwealth government proposes to make that affect the Australian wine industry. The way this argument is best described in a shorthand way is to say that the small wine producers, who are most of the wine producers in Australia, would prefer to change the basis of tax calculation to a volumetric one away from the ad valorem basis that applies. They want that because they believe it is a fairer tax for them and it would provide as well, without going into the full argument, health consequences to the wider community. They also argue, as does the entire wine industry, that the total take from the wine industry is excessive under the new arrangements and that there has been a grab for cash by the government under the guise of introducing a new tax here. I think the arguments on that score are basically valid.

On the question of the small wine producers, the Australian wine industry is a success story of Australian industry. It is one of the industries that give Australia an international reputation. It is a fast growing industry that proposes to export about $1 billion of wine this year. It is a decentralised industry that provides jobs in regional Australia, and its future is inextricably bound up with wine tourism and the tourist industry to create occupations that otherwise would not exist for people by not only showing tourists the sites but also taking them to the local winery to sample a drop of the local grape.

talk.start.para: —That is why your government was the first to double the tax.

—You are disorderly, Senator. Behave yourself. So there is a need to amend the government legislation so that the small wineries of Australia are not penalised under the changes proposed by the government. We have made recommendations to do that. I foreshadow now that when the bills come before the chamber we will move down that course. (Time expired)

—I thank Senator Murray for deferring to me and for speaking after me. Alcohol taxation is an area that I have been involved with over a number of years, as honourable senators will know. As it is a drug that wreaks significant havoc on individuals and society, the Greens have immense concerns about what we as a parliament can do to help minimise the negative impacts of alcohol abuse in our community.

speech.para: I have been involved in the designer drink issue. As senators would remember, I have been in this chamber again and again to speak about a commonsense approach to dealing with alcohol as alcohol, not in terms of what produced the alcohol—whether it was wine based or spirit based. In their election promises the government said they were going to deal with that, and we have not seen them dealing with it yet.

So when the government's WET proposal came up in the ANTS package the Greens obviously were highly interested in the issue. The first point to be made is that this wine equalisation tax does not go far enough. It relates to wine and a couple of other drinks like cider and sake. The Greens would like to see serious taxation reform of all alcoholic products, with public health and safety being in the forefront of the policy makers' minds. It is, of course, important that the tax system ensure the viability and diversity amongst the various players in the alcohol industry but it has to be remembered that alcohol abuse has serious implications for our community and that as a parliament we should be proactive about it.

The most frustrating thing is that there is a proactive path that we as a parliament could be taking. There is an option that has been on the table for a long time. It is a volumetric tax on the alcohol content. A tax on alcohol content would provide a strong incentive for the production and promotion of low alcohol drinks. And from a consumer perspective, low alcohol drinks would be cheaper, so there would be an incentive to buy and drink low alcohol drinks.

It makes so much sense, but the government is ignoring this option at the behest of the large bulk wine producers, primarily based in South Australia. It is noteworthy that one of the largest bulk producers, Southcorp, made significant donations to the coalition to the tune of $72,800 and to the ALP to the tune of $15,000 in the last financial year. This does not include the donations in the lead-up to the election. It is also interesting to note—it is not something I usually do—that Bruce Kemp, cousin of brothers Senator Rod and Mr David Kemp, is one of the executive officers of Southcorp.

It is therefore unsurprising that the government is maintaining the ad valorem system which makes cask wine incredibly cheap. It is also unsurprising that the ALP have not challenged this properly, despite the clear public health implications that have been documented by a number of esteemed drug research organisations such as the Alcohol and Other Drug Council and the National Centre for Research on Drug Abuse. This evidence is compelling, and it is disappointing that the major parties have failed to take it into account.

The minority report submitted by Senator Brown and me argues that there are immense difficulties with the wine equalisation tax. In its own terms, the wine equalisation tax—WET—proposal fails because of its inability to achieve revenue neutrality and the negative impact that the WET will have on the industry and on regions in which they are situated. This is especially so in my home state of Western Australia and in Senator Brown's home state of Tasmania, as evidenced by the motions moved in the houses of parliament there: the unanimous motion from the Tasmanian House of Assembly moved by Peg Putt from the Australian Greens and the unanimous motion in the WA Legislative Assembly moved after a motion on notice in the Legislative Council by Chrissie Sharp from the Greens (WA).

In the broader framework of public health, the WET proposal has serious flaws because it totally fails to recognise that alcohol abuse is a major public concern and health issue, that the taxation system can be an effective tool to achieve socially responsible outcomes, and that the wine industry as a whole is likely to benefit to a greater extent from a volumetric tax.

This is one area where I think people should be representing their community and their state. But also, when you have a system on which as a national issue we are having drug summits and this is recognised again and again as probably one of the most important issues of drug abuse in Australia, it is crazy to see the government not taking the opportunity to take one of the most effective steps they can—that is, to recognise the impacts of alcohol and to tax according to the alcohol content.

I would leave the rest of the time for this debate as far as possible to other senators, as I realise I was not a full member of this committee, but I commend the minority report to the Senate and to the community to look at so they can argue about the issues involved.

talk.start.para: —I advise Senator Ferguson that I will only speak for five minutes, which will allow him enough time to address the issues at hand. This is the sixth report in this overall inquiry and the third from the overarching Senate Select Committee on A New Tax System. I think enough has been said already at previous discussions about the various things that have gone on in the committee. I just want to again thank both the chair and deputy chair for the work they have done during this inquiry and to thank the secretariat. I predict, Senator Cook, that political economists and others of such ilk will be picking over the Hansard records and the other records of the committee for many years to come.

speech.para: This particular report has three main elements. One is the Commonwealth-state financial relations element, the second is the wine equalisation tax and the third is luxury cars. The luxury cars area, although well reported in the report, is relatively uncontentious. As far as I can see, it has not generated much policy heat. The areas of policy interest have been primarily in Commonwealth-state relations and wine. At the Commonwealth-state level, a critical issue has been local government. We have had remarks made before as to how their position needs to be radically improved in this major change that is in prospect. I thank the government, inci dentally, for starting the process of recognising reforms in that area by some of the changes they have already indicated. But the critical thing to recognise is that, regardless of the origin of the Premier, what the premiers want is certainty in revenue and certainty in revenue growth and to be assured that the taxes applied to produce that certainty produce efficient economic outcomes and at the same time are fair for the community. I think those are the kinds of principles that should guide us when considering that issue.

On the wine equalisation tax issue, there is a great deal of division and debate. I do not really want to revisit that, because that is well canvassed in the report, but I do want to comment on a deficiency, I believe, in the government's approach to the alcohol area. That deficiency is primarily one of process. Alcohol is not just wine; alcohol is beer, spirits and other alcoholic beverages. I would note, for the intent of the Senate, that we do not have before us bills in this tax system package to deal with the ANTS proposals for changes to the spirits regime and to the beer regime. I think that is wrong, particularly when much of the argument about the wine equalisation tax has actually been from the national and state bodies to do with alcohol and drug abuse. They are concerned about how alcohol taxation influences the abuse of consumption of alcohol. They are supporters of the moderate consumption of alcohol. Not to have the beer and spirits bills to debate cognately with the wine bill I think is a mistake. I think it is bad process. What is more, it is a mistake which the government can rectify. We have probably a couple more weeks before we get to that stage of the debate, given the break we have next week for estimates, and I would urge the government to get before us the beer and spirits excise proposals arising out of the ANTS package which they put to the people. That is an important aspect which has probably been skipped over in this.

Finally, I would like to commend to senators the tables at the back of my supplementary report. Fortunately, the Distilled Spirits Council of Australia put in to the committee some very clear and illustrative tables which are very helpful in understanding a complicated area. I have adapted those for my purposes, but I want to record my debt to them. One of the major problems with discussing this area is a lack of understanding as to what products fall into what categories, how they are dealt with and so on. I would suggest that those tables are actually helpful for a better understanding of alcohol taxation in that area.

talk.start.para: —Firstly, can I say that I have been at a meeting all day and, while I knew the report was being tabled, I was unaware that anybody was going to be speaking to the report. I thought it was going to be tabled some time after half past three because of other business that was before the Senate. So I have not had time to read in detail the reports of the Labor Party members and the Democrats. However, I did have an opportunity while Senator Murray was speaking to read in brief some of the things that were said.

speech.para: I am disappointed in the start of the Labor senators' report, because they make it sound as though the government was not prepared to hold any public hearings in relation to these matters that were referred to us by Senator Murray, namely, luxury cars, the wine equalisation tax and Commonwealth-state relations. In fact, that is not the case. The government offered public hearings on any one night in the week prior to this report having to be tabled, last week, and this was rejected by the Labor senators. We said we were prepared to have a hearing either on Wednesday or Thursday night of last week, and in conversation with me the chairman said that they did not want to have them those nights but they would like to have them the next week and extend the reporting date. Once the matter had been referred by Senator Murray with a reporting date of today, I do not think it was fair to extend the reporting date when in fact we were ready to hold public hearings in that previous week. So, for the report by Labor senators to give the impression that the government senators did not want to hold public hearings is quite wrong. You certainly did not get government support to extend the deadline, but I do not think you would have got Democrats' support either to extend the deadline, because Senator Murray referred it and to the best of my knowledge he too thought we should stick to the original deadline.

However, we did have lots of evidence put before us prior to these bills being referred specifically. We heard evidence at many of our select committee hearings from the Winemakers Federation in particular and also from two state governments. Let me say that, as for their report's introduction, I am surprised and I think it is somewhat misleading to suggest that we would not have hearings. They also say:
The Government has consistently and fraudulently claimed that Labor Premiers support its GST package. Nothing could be further from the truth.
They should consider all of the public statements from state premiers, particularly Labor premiers, that have been quoted. When you have the New South Wales Labor Premier saying:

I have got to say that I have never been at a more successful Premiers' Conference in the four years that I have been in this job. It does seem a transformation. It is the national government handing over a growth tax that is going to be the basis for state revenues from now on in. . . It gives us a growth tax in place of small and messy business taxes that we have had to count on as we have tried to meet people's needs for schools, hospitals and so on—
that does not sound to me like a premier who does not support the package. Mr Beattie, the Queensland Premier, says:
Queensland if the GST goes through—it is a matter for the Senate—will be better off.
That does not sound to me like a premier that does not support the package. The Tasmanian Premier, Mr Bacon, says:
I'm the first Tasmanian leader to go to Canberra and come away no worse off.

That does not sound to me like a Labor premier that is not supporting the package. So we have this number of Labor premiers who obviously support this package and, as for Labor Party senators saying that we fraudulently claim that Labor premiers support the tax reform package, I think nothing could be further from the truth.

They supplement that by a table on page 44 of the report. It has been identified as a table that was presented last November by the South Australian government and which has no status and no relevance because it has been superseded by a subsequent Premiers Conference. An intergovernmental agreement was signed in April which simply overtakes all of the matters that are raised in this table. It was not a table that was presented to us as evidence. It was a table that has been somehow obtained by the Labor Party, who put in their own report a document that was never presented to the select committee as evidence, never tabled and never included in Hansard. It was just simply something that was obtained by the Labor Party and it is put in their report as though it is an official document.

talk.start.para: —Most unusual.

—Most unusual indeed, Senator Vanstone. I think it is rather misleading to use a document that has no status or no relevance. Senator Margetts spoke about the wine industry and the WET tax, and I must speak briefly about that. She criticises the influence that she says South Australia has, particularly the impact of the large wine producers in South Australia.

speech.para: It is true that South Australia produces 50 per cent of Australia's wine but let me tell you that the advice given to us as a committee by the peak body in Australia—the Winemakers Federation, which represents large producers of wine and also over 400 small winemakers in Australia—was that they requested this government to continue with an ad valorem tax.

The peak body represents some 80 per cent of the crush in Australia and at least half of the small winemakers in Australia, bearing in mind that some of the small winemakers do not belong to any organisation. We do have some in Western Australia which I know do not like the system and some in Tasmania who do not like the system but they represent a very small proportion of Australia's wine industry and the total crush. So we listened to the peak body as they made representations to us and the decision was made.

In relation to the WET tax and the bills that relate to that, we went to the election with two clear things in mind. One was that the base of the tax would be a four-litre cask of wine. In fact, we said that we would introduce a WET tax to replace the existing wholesale sales taxes which would not increase the price of a four-litre cask of wine greater than the 1.9 per cent CPI impact that the overall indirect tax package would have on the economy. So we have set the WET tax rate at 29 per cent, which actually increases the price of a cask of wine by 1.9 per cent.

In agreeing to the peak body's request that we have an ad valorem tax, it stands as a matter of fact that, if you are going to tax wine by value and not by volume, the higher the value of a bottle of wine the more tax is paid on it; it just stands to reason. So in fact we had the situation where we agreed that we would only increase the price of a cask of wine by the average CPI and we acceded to the Winemakers Federation request that we have an ad valorem tax. But the effect of that is that the price of a premium wine will go up by slightly more than the 1.9 per cent that a cask of wine will go up by.

But what is not mentioned by those who complain about the rate of WET tax is the saving in production costs that will happen through the introduction of a GST. Nothing is said about the saving in transport costs. Nothing is said about the fact that the GST will not be on exports and neither will the WET tax, so exports will remain very competitive. The other thing that was not mentioned—

talk.start.para: —Nothing about high rollers getting concessions. Nothing about Ron Walker getting his money.
—Order!

—Senator Conroy, just because there is no time for you to speak in this debate—because your committee chairman, Senator Cook, took the whole 10 minutes—I would appreciate it if I could be allowed to finish. You will have another chance in a couple of weeks time. Nothing is mentioned, when we are talking about the tax, about the fact that—

speech.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators will cease interjecting. Senator Ferguson has the call.

—Nothing is mentioned about the fact that Australians are going to be delivered $13 billion worth of tax cuts which will make wine more affordable. So the people who are complaining the most about the fact that they believe that premium wine is increasing by more than the 1.9 per cent are in fact those people who currently buy premium wine and will still be able to afford to buy it. The other thing is that we wanted to make sure that people on low incomes will still be able to enjoy a glass of wine at a reasonable price. Many of those are people who do buy casks and casks will still be in their affordable range.

speech.para: I know I am getting very close to time but I want to say that this is, thankfully, the final report of the Select Committee On A New Tax System. In doing so, I want to give my thanks to my colleagues on the committee. Some were easier to get on with than others, but I will not name Senator Conroy. I would like to thank the committee secretariat for all of the work that it has done and my colleagues on the committee, who have worked very hard over a very stressful time for four months to produce the number of reports that have been produced and particularly to get this final report out on time. I say to the chairman, Senator Cook, and to all of the other people who have been on the committee: I hope that the committee's work has been of value and that, when we finally pass the new tax reform package before 30 June, all of our work will have been worth while.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Legislation

talk.start.para: —Senator Sherry asked how many of the government's amendments represent policy change and how many reflect changes of a technical nature. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

para.inline: Senator Sherry asked: of the Government's amendments, how many represent policy change and how many reflect changes of a technical nature.

speech.para: The Government has circulated amendments relating to over 30 issues. Some of these issues take several discrete amendments to implement, so that the total number of Government amendments is quoted as 128. The amendments incorporate suggestions made during the wide ranging and very constructive consultations we have undertaken since the tax reform Bills were introduced. With the assistance of a number of professional and industry representatives, and input from community organisations, we have continued to look for ways of making the design and the operation of the GST even better.

The amendments are mostly technical, in the nature of fine-tuning of the Bill. Only 3 issues could be said to relate to new policy initiatives. These 3 measures do not involve significant revenue cost, being relatively minor, but important, amendments to operational aspects of the GST announced in ANTS.
The policy changes:
. Allow charities to account on a cash basis, regardless of their turnover;
. Extend GST grouping provisions to include certain partnerships and trusts; and

. Refine the change of creditable use provisions, so that no adjustments will be required for purchases of inputs less than $10,000 used to make financial supplies or less than $1,000 for items of private use.
These amendments merely refine the Bills to ensure that the Government's policy is carried through in the most practical, efficient and cost effective way possible.

Earlier today, in reference to high rollers I said that meals, gambling and accommodation are not subject to wholesale sales tax, and that is true. I also made reference to Verve Cliquot. Wholesale sales tax does apply to wines, including Verve Cliquot, but the restaurant mark-up does not include the wholesale sales tax. If the government's tax bills are passed, these mark-ups will be subject to GST. As I mentioned, meals, accommodation and gambling will also be subject to GST.

subdebateinfo.title: Rugby League: Retirement of Bob Fulton and Allan Langer

talk.start.para: —This afternoon I rise to make some remarks not about the GST, which has been discussed at length in this chamber over the past two weeks, but about the great game of Rugby League, which is an issue of some importance to the public of Australia, particularly in the eastern states. As we know, Rugby League has been through some very turbulent times over the last few years. The Super League-ARL war split the game and threatened to bring about its demise. In more recent times, there have been scandals with respect to the use of performance enhancing drugs and steroids and, more lately, some rather unsavoury incidents have occupied the headlines.

speech.para: It is unfortunate that in this climate we have seen the retirement from this great game of two of the legends of Rugby League. I refer in particular to Bob Fulton, the recently retired coach of Manly, and to Allan Langer, who retired this week. Both of these individuals are legends, in my view—and I think in the view of the general public, whether they follow Rugby League or not. Rugby League has great players and it has good players, but there are few legends. These two were both legends.

Bob Fulton, I would have to admit, was neither the most popular Rugby League player in Australia nor a popular coach, particularly with referees and with the fans of every other club except Manly. I have to confess that I have been a long-term fan of Bob Fulton and, indeed, of the Manly club. In my early years I was a supporter of Manly. I am not sure why, other than that I happened to get interested in Rugby League around the time that Bob Fulton commenced his great career. When I was a youngster, there was no player—I suppose until Wally Lewis came along—who so dominated the game.

Bob Fulton was a person of incredible individual ability who could, within a few seconds, turn a game around. It was not until Cronulla entered the competition that I switched my allegiance to my local club. Nevertheless, I found myself rather divided in the 1973 grand final, reputed to be the most hard-fought grand final in Rugby League history, when Manly beat Cronulla. Cronulla had Tommy Bishop, another genius of the Rugby League world, and other great players, and Manly had Bob Fulton. It was only through the brilliance of Fulton that they won that game.

Fulton played a total of 213 first-grade games for Manly and 50 games for Eastern Suburbs. He also played in 20 tests for Australia and 15 World Cup matches. There is no doubt he would have played in more had he been picked for the 1967 Kangaroo tour. He toured twice, in 1973 and 1978, and in the views of many he should have been picked to play for Australia earlier. He had an enviable coaching record, having coached Australia in 39 tests for 32 wins and he never lost a series. All told, he coached teams in 405 first-class matches, which is a record in Rugby League. It was sad to see him retire as the coach. I think he probably would have preferred to go out at the end of this year, but the time was of his own choosing—to give someone else the chance to try to resurrect the fortunes of the Manly club.

Whilst I know that just about every other Rugby League supporter in the country supports two teams—their own and whoever is playing Manly—and do not necessarily wish any improvement in Manly's fortunes, I think people recognise that the game has lost one of its greatest individual players and coaches. He is certainly a legend—a person who played the game in the spirit in which it was intended, albeit he did from time to time have some rather strained relations with referees. But, there again, that is what referees are there for—to cop a bit but at the end of the day to have their decisions always accepted. Fulton always did that, however reluctantly.

I now turn of course to this week. We saw the announcement of Allan Langer's retirement from the game. I suppose there are a lot of differences between Langer and Fulton, but there are a lot of similarities as well. Firstly, they are both small in stature but huge in heart. They were both totally committed 80-minute players. They were both individually brilliant and, in my view, both legends of the game. I put Allan Langer in the same category as Fulton, Gasnier and others.

Allan Langer proved that little men can play the game and have an impact—and what a huge impact he had. He started playing for Queensland under the leadership of Wally Lewis and eventually succeeded in the captaincy of the Broncos and of Queensland. He established an unparalleled record for his club, his state and his country. All told he played some 240 premiership games and scored 401 points; he played in numerous state of origin matches, playing 30 games for Queensland; and he played in 22 tests for Australia, including captaining Australia in two tests.

Langer represents what everybody recognises, and what has been reported in the media this week, as the good side of Rugby League—that is, firstly, total dedication to your team, to your sport and particularly to your team mates. He was a quiet achiever, a cheeky player with a great sense of humour. He was not one to stand in awe of himself, rather he went out there and played the game as it should be played. Whilst he no doubt enjoyed the events after a game of football, like all other players, particularly after a premiership win or an origin series win, he always did the game, his club, his state and his country proud.

I think it is important to recognise, as we have done on many occasions in this parliament, the exploits of great sportsmen and women and most recently, of course, the retirement of Mark Taylor from international cricket. I think it is fitting that we record a few comments noting the retirement of both Allan Langer and Bob Fulton. Langer, again in my view—and I know in the view of many fans and supporters—has retired too early, but that is a selfish attitude that we as fans adopt. I would have loved to have seen him continue to play for the rest of this year and into the future but, after all, it was his decision, he chose the time to go and we respect him for that.

As I said, I believe that it is appropriate to place on the record the thanks of hundreds of thousands of fans around Australia to these two great players. I just hope that, after this weekend's round of Rugby League matches, we can be celebrating again the exploits of players and teams rather than some of the more unsavoury incidents which unfortunately are detracting from this great game at the present time.

subdebateinfo.title: Rugby League: Retirement of Bob Fulton and Allan Langer
Constitutional Change

talk.start.para: —Before I begin my remarks this afternoon, I cannot resist the opportunity to both note and endorse Senator Forshaw's words in relation to two great Australian Rugby League footballers, Bob Fulton and Allan Langer. I would be remiss of course not to record my own lifelong commitment to what I regard is the greatest southern Sydney club, the St George-Illawarra Dragons. Senator Forshaw and I might have a debate on that question. In relation to the game they play in heaven, which is being played at the Sydney Football Stadium on Saturday, let us hope the Waratahs are successful over the Reds.

speech.para: I do however want to take some time this afternoon to address the issue of constitutional change. In the last 12 months an enormous amount has happened in this area—whether it was conventions, preambles or other issues, the notion of constitutional reform has remained at the forefront of public debate. I think that is a very good thing. Many senators would be aware of the valuable work of the Constitutional Centenary Foundation, which is chaired by Donald McDonald. In fact, our colleague Senator the Hon. Amanda Vanstone, the Minister for Justice and Customs, is on the Board of Advisers of the foundation. Throughout 1997 and 1998 the foundation ran a series of local constitutional conventions in conjunction with the Australian Local Government Association. They culminated today here in Canberra with the completion of a forum which has run over the past three days.

The aim of the conventions was to bring together a range of participants from across the country to discuss five key areas: the Constitution as a national symbol—looking at the preamble, changing the Constitution and issues of citizenship and the position of indigenous Australians; parliament and the election of representatives—looking at both houses of the federal parliament as well as state and local governments; the question of an Australian republic; the federal system—discussing the structure of our federation, the division of powers, tax and revenue distribution and recognising local government; and citizens and rights. All in all over 3,000 Australians took part in 58 conventions held across 66 local council areas. In my area of western Sydney the Parramatta Council held one of these conventions, which focused on two of the five areas—the republic and the rights of citizens.

This week's forum at Old Parliament House provided an opportunity to synthesise the outcomes of the individual conventions and to make recommendations about the agenda and format for any future constitutional convention. I think it is important that the broader issues of constitutional reform are being discussed. I think it is crucial that Australians do not labour under the misapprehension that all our Constitution does is install the Queen as our head of state. The Attorney-General, the Hon. Daryl Williams, who is also on the board of the foundation, addressed the forum this week and made the important point that `the government is conscious that there is currently a range of constitutional issues beyond the republic and preamble issues which could usefully be addressed'.

In the whole debate about constitutional change one of the issues that is important to me is the role and involvement of women in that process. Early last year I was pleased to participate in the excellent Women's Constitutional Convention, held in this parliament. I made the point when I addressed that convention that, when the first conventions were held, our grandmothers and our great grandmothers did not have the opportunity to influence the future direction of their nation in any significant way—they certainly were not delegates to the conventions for a start. It would be a grave pity if we did not seize the opportunity offered by the current climate of debate to ensure that that sort of history does not repeat itself.

I am pleased to see that interested Australian women have continued to be at the forefront of the debate on change, and particularly notable is the recent establishment of the Women for an Australian Republic home page. It provides news updates, information on the proposed republican model to be considered at the referendum and details of the women's convention that I just referred to, as well as a range of other information on Internet sites and in newspapers and other publications. Importantly, though, it provides a forum for discussion of issues surrounding constitutional change and a facility to ask questions about aspects of the debate. So, whether you are already active in the debate or whether you are just beginning to develop an interest in the debate, it is a vehicle for expression or a source of information so that you can participate.

I also want to make brief mention of the Young Australians for a Republic, an organisation of younger Australians with an interest in matters of progressive constitutional change. They are not a wing of the Australian Republican Movement, they are not party political; they are purely focused on promoting the move to an Australian republic. They played a very big role in the successful `Yes' coalition conference held in Canberra earlier this year. I think one of the highlights of that conference was a session organised by Young Australians for a Republic where they looked at issues such as how to promote a `yes' vote to young Australians and how to encourage their peers to take an active interest in future debate. In the interests of effective communication, they have also established a home page and have an active email discussion list to facilitate involvement.

I referred earlier to the Constitutional Centenary Foundation. It also involves many young Australians, particularly through the National Schools Convention which was held in Canberra last year. Many of us met those participants and saw their interest in, and their enthusiasm for, the issue. The National Youth Round Table, which was convened in Canberra in March this year, in its communique also recommended support for constitutional change. I think the views of these young Australians are very important.

I was interested in the debate which occurred yesterday in the chamber on the question of the opening of the Olympics. I happen to think that it is very important that we do not get caught in base political confrontation about some of these important issues. That might sound funny coming from a politician, but both the opening of the Olympics and the question of an Australian president are issues that deserve to be approached in a calm and thoughtful manner; not, in my view, reduced to the sometimes fairly base levels of party politics.

We heard yesterday reminiscences about the night Sydney won the right to host the Olympic Games. My own recollections are particularly vivid given that, at the time, I was working with the Hon. John Fahey, then Premier of New South Wales, known for ever more after that evening, I think, as `Jumping Jack'. Many other Australians have equally vivid and exciting memories of the announcement. Many Australians will undoubtedly look back on the Olympics hoping to remember the performance of Australia's teams, the medals, the hard work, the glory and the achievement. I hope that as we move closer to the games those memories are not marred by petty political manoeuvring.

I recently had the honour of giving an occasional lecture at a graduation ceremony at the University of Western Sydney, an institution of which I have spoken on a number of occasions in the Senate. In giving that address to new graduates, I took the opportunity of discussing both the impending referendum and the issue of constitutional change. I drew an analogy with the pace of change in our constantly evolving world where, in information technology terms, something like 65,000 new sites are being added to the Internet every hour of every day. We are progressing towards a new century with problems and opportunities unlike any faced by past generations, at a pace and intensity that is unparalleled. How we cope with that as a society is a very important question. Even this parliament deals with things in a different manner from that used in decades and generations past. From the simple capacity of members of the public to choose to watch question time on television—although one might occasionally wonder—to the capacity of constituents to readily download legislation from the Internet, these are all points of change.

The point I made was that ongoing debate about the republic is all about how we deal with change as a community. It is my personal belief that the move to a republic is a natural incremental change with which Australia is more than capable of dealing. It represents not a radical change in our national identity but a development of the Australian story that has been emerging for many years.

I referred earlier to the speech of the Attorney-General to the forum yesterday where he outlined the process from this point in time to the point of the referendum. He noted that the enactment of the Constitutional Alteration (Establishment of a Republic) Bill:

. . . would not greatly change the basic governmental arrangements that have served Australia so well. Nor would it graft another country's republic model onto these arrangements. It would change some titles, but not the basic operation of our system of national government.

The Attorney also commented on the ongoing nature of the debate on constitutional reform. In particular, he referred to the recommendation of the Constitutional Convention that, should Australia move to a republic, the government should convene another convention to discuss further reform. He made the point that in two weeks, with all its attendant experts, the Constitutional Convention effectively considered a single issue: that of the republic. So debating other constitutional change is important. It is being pursued, but it needs to be done in a patient and considered manner without haste or undue complication.

subdebateinfo.title: Chicken Meat Industry: Newcastle Disease

talk.start.para: —I just wanted to take the opportunity of the adjournment debate this evening to make some brief comments about the outbreak of virulent Newcastle disease on broiler farms at Mangrove Mountain, New South Wales, which occurred earlier this month—in fact, on 1 April.

speech.para: This outbreak is already disastrous. It has already had disastrous consequences for the farmers who have seen their livelihood destroyed, for the processors and for the many thousands of jobs that rely on the processing of chicken meat in Australia, but particularly in the Hunter Valley, in the Gosford area north of Sydney, and also further up into the valley itself. It also has the potential to be disastrous for the whole chicken industry if the efforts to isolate and control the outbreak are not successful. It is also potentially disastrous for the disease status of Australia in relation to our WTO undertakings. Today we must be hopeful that the Mangrove Mountain outbreak has been contained after a substantial effort from the industry and through state and federal government cooperation.

A suspect broiler farm on Peats Ridge, outside the Mangrove Mountain restricted area, has now been shown to be negative to the virulent Newcastle disease virus. This is, of course, very good news. The National Consultative Committee on Emergency Animal Diseases met again the night before last to consider test results from that broiler farm on Peats Ridge. Genetic testing of the isolated virus from the farm at the Australian Animal Health Laboratory at Geelong showed that broiler birds were infected, but that they were infected with a known, low virulent Australian strain of Newcastle disease.

Under existing arrangements, the federal Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, all states and territories, emergency services and Defence personnel are involved in assisting New South Wales Agriculture to manage the outbreak. As I said a moment ago, I understand that the cooperation has been very good.

As of this morning more than one million birds have been destroyed on the Mangrove Mountain ridge, and I understand that 900 people are assisting New South Wales Agriculture to depopulate and decontaminate the farms on Mangrove Mountain. Scientists believe that the outbreak of viruses is derived from Australian strains of a non-pathogenic Newcastle disease virus, rather than from an imported strain. There is no known linkage to imported birds or products.

I hope that this potential crisis in the industry can be alleviated. But it is extremely important for those people already affected by the outbreak to understand that there are many of us in the federal parliament who feel the pain they are going through when they see their livelihoods destroyed. I ask that we keep our fingers crossed that there are no further outbreaks of the virulent strain.

subdebateinfo.title: Electorate Offices: Equipment
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 451)

talk.start.para: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 8 March 1999:

question.para: (1) When did the department last undertake a physical inspection of electorate offices and account for equipment owned or leased by the department.
(2) Were any of the assets not able to be accounted for; if so, what was the total value of the assets not accounted for.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The department undertakes a rolling program of physical inspections of all electorate offices throughout each parliamentary term. In addition, all regions conducted inspections of the electorate offices of those senators and members who either retired or were defeated at the last federal election.

Since outsourcing the provision of Information Technology (IT) services to electorate offices on 1 July 1998, ownership of IT equipment in electorate offices has been transferred to CSC Australia Pty Ltd. That organisation is responsible for conducting physical inspections of the IT equipment in electorate offices. With the upgrading of all IT equipment greater than three years old in electorate offices currently in progress, some seventy percent of electorate offices have recently been physically inspected.

(2) No assets were unaccounted for in either the last round of rolling inspections or in the ad-hoc inspections conducted in the electorate offices of those senators and members who either retired or were defeated at the last federal election.
CSC has advised that in the seventy percent of electorate offices inspected so far there have been no instances of missing equipment.

subdebateinfo.title: Electorate Offices: Replacement Printers
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 452)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 8 March 1999:

question.para: (1) What was the rationale for the decision to replace the HP LaserJet 4si Printer with the Lexmark Optra Printer.
(2) What advice was sought and received from staff, including electorate officers, prior to this decision being taken

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) HP4Si printers were introduced into electorate offices in July of 1994. Due to their age, spare parts were becoming difficult to source which made swift problem resolution difficult.

The Lexmark Optra Printer (S1855) was chosen as a replacement printer as a result of an evaluation conducted by CSC Australia Pty Ltd, which is responsible for the provision of Information Technology (IT), services to electorate offices. CSC found that:
* The Lexmark S1855 was not susceptible to jamming or poor print quality;
* it had a superior graphics function;
* the printer driver was easy to use, whilst providing a greater number of options; and
* commissioning a second Lexmark printer within the office would allow all computers to utilise the same type of network printing software.

(2) Between August and December 1998 the proposed new printers were tested in five electorate offices. This was later expanded to twelve offices. All the feedback except that from one office was of a positive nature. That office preferred the old printer. The perceived deficiencies of the Lexmark printer were addressed by training the office staff in how to set the machine's default tray options.
